entry.title: SAP Master Data Governance - Roadmap Session at SAP Sapphire 2025
entry.content:
I recently discussed the topic of master data management in various sessions at Sapphire 2025, Orlando. For example, I discussed how to get more complete, accurate, and compliant enterprise data with a modern master data management system and what is MDM's role in data fabric, data product, and AI initiatives.

Fully packed session at Sapphire 2025

I also outlined  our plans for the SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) solution portfolio in a roadmap session:

Session title

The MDG roadmap session again saw a large crowd of attendees at this year's Sapphire and our growth and development plans for the MDG portfolio resonated well with the audience. But I know that not everybody can travel to Orlando, I hence would like to share the news with everybody who couldn't join. (The slides below are the ones that I used in the Sapphire roadmap session.)

Please note that the roadmap disclaimer is indicating that future items are subject to change applies.

Solution Introduction

To get started, let me very briefly explain what SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) is, and which topics it addresses.

SAP Master Data Governance at a glance

MDG is an application to manage master data, it provides preconfigured, domain-specific master data governance to monitor, find and correct data quality issues. You can either centrally create, change, and distribute, or you can consolidate master data coming from different systems in your entire enterprise landscape.

MDG is one application for all master data. It is not only for SAP master data. It does come with a lot of out-of-the-box, domain-specific capabilities that are, of course, based on SAP’s data models and business logic. But it is also a platform that is used by many customers to build master data governance processes on extended data models and completely custom-defined master data domains.

SAP Master Data Governance key capabilities

 From our customers, we understand that the purpose of master data management is to improve the quality of master data and to establish a corporate-wide understanding of it, enabling them to run and optimize their business based on a trusted master data foundation.

As you probably know, companies take different approaches to MDM. For example, some allow for de-central ownership of master data, and create a common understanding by using master data consolidation to create key mapping between detected duplicates and to create a golden record. Others prefer central ownership of master data and distribute master data that is always created in high quality. Some companies decide to take a de-central approach for some domains, like customer master data, and a central approach for other domains, for example, when introducing new products. On top of that, many companies constantly monitor how the quality of master data evolves. And then they react if they find issues.

MDG supports all these approaches and also all combinations of these approaches in a very integrated and organized way, and this is very much appreciated by our customers. This allows you to combine approaches as required to cover all use cases and all implementation styles, for a complete enterprise master data management program with just one solution: SAP MDG.

Strategy and Vision

Our strategy and vision for MDG have been very consistent for years, and we are successfully executing this vision. Our MDG product strategy is not an isolated strategy just for MDG - it is embedded into SAP’s broader strategy and vision, which is outlined in this slide.

SAP vision bringing together applications, data, and AI

Through SAP’s unparalleled applications, our end-to-end business processes connect all parts of an organization. This ensures processes are smooth, consistent, and ready for AI-driven improvements.

SAP can also provide unmatched data, because by harmonizing information from SAP and non-SAP sources into one unified Business Data Cloud, we give AI agents a 360-degree perspective, and everything is instantly ‘understood’ in its business context.

When you then bring the right data to specialized AI agents orchestrated by SAP Joule, you unlock continuous optimization across lines of business. Instead of isolated automation, you get an interconnected system that learns, adapts, and improves at scale. We think that this is the best approach to AI.

This synergy between applications, data, and AI is the driving force behind the SAP Business Suite. 

SAP MDG supporting the new era of enterprise management

The graphic above illustrates how MDG will support SAP’s broader vision of bringing together applications, data, and AI. Let me start from the bottom:

As pointed out before, SAP offers a suite of applications with end-to-end scenarios – and not just isolated applications. Accordingly, we have built MDG not just as a solution “next to” applications. Of course, MDG can be an MDM solution for any heterogeneous application landscape. But in the context of SAP applications, we can offer much more integration. We have shown this with scenarios embedded into SAP S/4HANA, or with federated MDG deployments across an application landscape, or with integrated scenarios across SAP Ariba Supplier and Lifecycle Performance and MDG.

When we look at SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), this provides semantically rich data from various data sources, and master data often is the most critical data asset. MDG curates this master data towards a trustful and high-quality treasure, really unlocking the value of other business data, or also feeding into 360 views via Intelligent Apps as well as data products within BDC.

When it comes to Artificial Intelligence and MDG there are two key aspects: on the one hand MDG leverages AI technology for process automation to speed up MDG processing. But more importantly, the trusted high-quality master data in MDG, provided to all applications and to SAP BDC, truly enables SAP Business AI across all SAP standard and custom-built AI scenarios and agents.

SAP Master Data Governance in SAP Business Suite

The SAP Business Suite represents the culmination of SAP’s overall vision for the future of enterprise management. It combines core ERP and Line of Business applications, and it is fueled by business data and meaningful AI. It is a comprehensive, integrated set of solutions designed to seamlessly connect and optimize every function across your enterprise. This solution architecture, as shown in the graphic above, ensures that all parts of your business operate in sync, unlocking agility, efficiency, and innovation.

In this context, you may ask yourself where SAP MDG fits in: SAP MDG is technically built on the SAP Business Technology Platform and commercially part of the BTP. And it is truly the enabler of the SAP Business Suite’s applications and of SAP Business Data Cloud by providing trusted and high-quality master data for flawless end-to-end business processes, trustful insights, and reliable automation through Business AI.

Investment drivers for SAP Master Data GovernanceHow does this translate into the strategic investments that we are planning for SAP MDG’s roadmap? Our roadmap for MDG is driven by the integrated vision and value proposition of the SAP Business Suite, and by customer needs and master data management market trends that arise in this context.

With the benefits of the SAP Business Suite at hand, SAP can provide much more value to our customers than just any MDM tool provider, because we understand how master data is used in business contexts. Leveraging this understanding, we create benefits for our customers. We can provide master data management capabilities that truly support all domains, all industries, and all approaches, embedded into the business. We have proven this with MDG, and we will continue to deliver on this unique promise. 

In addition, we see certain trends in the market, which will be laid out in in more detail further below. But let's start with highlighting how interrelated these trends are.

For example, new sources for trusted data in the cloud, or data sharing in business networks in the cloud will allow for more automation in keeping your master data records up to date.

Or take the fact that digitization or the application of artificial intelligence demands for higher volumes and better quality of master data, and therefore needs more automation in master data management.

As we know, the market for business application software is moving towards modular but integrated applications and towards the cloud. For most companies, this move to the cloud is not one single step. To facilitate a step-by-step journey, modularization is a key enabler that allows to also move MDM capabilities to the cloud step-by-step, as required by the applications.

Cloud as strategy driver

Let’s come to the first trend: the cloud. When business applications are moving to the cloud, the master data itself needs to be provided there. Of course, this is possible with MDG today. But in addition, we will continue to provide cloud-based master data integration services on the SAP Business Technology Platform. We will also build out data quality services as microservices in the cloud. We currently offer Address-Validation-as-a-Service against always up-to-date address directories, in the cloud.

I already mentioned that a stepwise move of business applications to the cloud demands for a modular approach to MDM. We are addressing this need with federation of MDG. This will, by the way, also help to meet the increasingly local compliance regulations. Modularization and cloud consumption will also enable our customers to get to a positive return on investment much faster and to grow their enterprise MDM program exactly in the pace needed for their strategic business initiatives.

Strategy drivers: digitization and AI

I think we all agree that master data is the key resource of any digital transformation and AI initiative. We will enhance MDG to help companies to become more intelligent, more agile, and to always process data compliantly.

Digitization and AI will demand for modular, specialized business applications, and we will help to provide harmonized, high-quality master data to these applications to enable end-to-end processes for intelligent enterprises. The key drivers we are focusing on in MDG are automation enablement, efficiency, and master data quality management. 

In the modular application landscape of the future, it will be a challenge to provide frictionless digital processes. SAP’s Business Technology Platform will be the foundation to achieve this. SAP Business Data Cloud for SAP and non-SAP integration will enable this. And this will provide our customers with a very high return on their investment into master data quality, because SAP’s common data foundation will allow to then broadly apply artificial intelligence as well as analytical scenarios to all data, and this is then powered by high-quality master data provided by MDG. This means that every investment in enhancing master data with MDG will yield significant returns in all your data-driven scenarios on top of SAP BTP and BDC. 

We also continue to see clear proof of this interrelation of digitization and investments into master data management, as many of the current SAP S/4HANA transformation programs at our customers use MDG to prepare this fundamental move for their company.

Strategy driver: automation

As pointed out before, digitization and AI are key drivers for automation in MDM. We will leverage SAP’s deep knowledge in business applications, analytics, and business networks to reduce the need for manual tasks in achieving high master data quality. 

We leverage third-party data providers to drive automation in master data creation. We provide ways to predict master data attribute values from an application context, and we continue to use more artificial intelligence to support master data quality tasks. This will help to reduce the human effort in MDM and to avoid errors created by humans, and to avoid the effort it takes to correct these human errors.

This kind of automation will need an agile, rapidly-scaling MDM solution that can be extended fast, scales quickly, and easily integrates with new systems, new business processes and new data types. We think that in the long run, a modular approach to MDM might be more effective to meet this agility, more effective than a monolithic approach.

 

Strategy driver: modularization

 

Let’s now focus on federation/modularization. I have pointed out how a more modular application landscape requires a modular approach to MDM, and what other benefits in agility, speed, efficiency, and TCO we expect from that approach. Therefore, we provide this additional deployment option for MDG. This can be an option for companies that plan to balance central and decentral MDG processes instead of using a fully centrally managed MDG approach. This can for example be an alternative for very heterogeneous companies running very differently set up business processes and application systems in their landscape, and, for example, also multiple differently configured SAP S/4HANA systems. 

We believe in providing choices and non-disruptive journeys for our customers. This is why this additional deployment option is not only for new customers, but it can also be used by existing customers by adding to their current implementation and safeguarding their investments into MDG.

As of today, most companies are using one single MDG system to centrally manage the master data for the complete enterprise. Of course, they can continue to do so. But for some companies, one single monolithic MDM system for the entire organization presents certain challenges already today. And as we discussed, this will even increase in the future.

The new approach with a federated MDG landscape will allow these companies to go for a more modular approach. We believe that we provide companies with a faster time to value, with increased flexibility that enables a broader MDM scope, and with a lower Total-Cost-of-Ownership. Federation allows companies to execute master data management as centrally as possible, but also as locally as needed by the diverse parts of the organization. They can really govern the data at the place where it is best understood. You can find further details in the blog post about the benefits of federation.

SAP Master Data Governance product versions

SAP offers options for consuming SAP Master Data Governance across the cloud and on premise, so companies can decide which deployment approach works best for them.

  • On the left-hand side, you see SAP MDG on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition – which can also be deployed on premise. This version is typically used for multi-domain, centralized governance across complete enterprises. It has pre-delivered business content across various domains (for example, business partner, customer, supplier, material, financial data), and there are solution extensions from SAP Partners. This version comes with a very flexible framework to extend processes or create custom master data objects that even meet the very complex needs of the largest enterprises.
  • In the middle, there is SAP MDG on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This is typically for organizations who are running SAP S/4HANA in the public cloud. This version currently focuses on business partner, customer, supplier, and product data. It is easy to consume and provides the processes for the very broad underlying S/4HANA data model.
  • And then, SAP Master Data Governance, cloud edition, shown on the right-hand side, is a software-as-a-service kick-start solution for the governance of core business partner data. 

We will continue to enhance all three versions of MDG. The strategy is for all versions of MDG to offer the same broad coverage of master data management processes across central governance, consolidation, data quality management and more. The two differences are: firstly, in the data model, which is either the very broad data model provided by SAP S/4HANA, or it is the core data model of SAP Business Technology Platform. The second difference is in how you can consume MDG, from a very easy to consume SaaS solution in the public cloud (on the right-hand side) to a robust private platform that supports even the most demanding customizations required by the world's largest companies (on the left-hand side).

Recent and Planned Innovations

I would now like to focus on some recent and planned innovations, and to explain how these relate to our product strategy. You may have already noticed the small graphic in the top right corner. It highlights which part of our strategy is addressed by each innovation.

Recent innovation: data provider integration

 

As mentioned earlier, digitization requires automation in MDM since lacking master data quality is a major barrier to innovation, to informed business decisions, and to the effective use of AI. We therefore invested into automation to help customers increase master data quality more efficiently with MDG. Automation in MDG always has two pillars. Pillar one is that leveraging trusted external data is much more efficient than typing it manually. And pillar two: we leverage technology – like AI – but also automated processes and rules-based automation.

The first recent innovation in this context is about automation with the help of trusted external data. We had already offered creation and enrichment of business partner data based on reference data from our partner Corporate Data Quality, who has access to more than 70 sources of trusted business partner data around the globe. Until recently, this was only possible in an interactive manner. We have now released a capability to add an automatic Reference Data Lookup step to MDG processes. This process step performs the search in the external data provider in the background and without user interaction. If this search finds a reference data record that is "good enough", it automatically takes over data, such as for example tax IDs and identification numbers and enriches the data in MDG. This further reduces the time users need to spend on master data management.

Recent innovation: generative AI for assisted changes and summary of changes

 Let's move on to two additional artificial intelligence scenarios that we have added recently.

  • The first one is “Summary of Changes”, which, for example, can help users who are approving master data changes. They get a natural language explanation of the requested changes.
  • The second scenario is “Assisted Change”. It allows users to change master data attributes using prompts in natural language. For example, people who are less trained or less experienced in master data management can communicate the intended change more easily to the system, and are then guided towards the right attributes in the data model that reflect their intended change.

We use Large Language Models for these capabilities, and customers can choose which LLM provider we should use. To achieve this, SAP has an abstraction layer, SAP’s AI foundation, which we leverage for our scenarios.

Planned innovation: integration with SAP Joule

Let's continue with the use of AI in MDG. The AI scenarios outlined earlier are directly embedded into MDG’s user interfaces. This way, they support users who already navigated into these UIs to work within MDG processes.

In addition, we have enabled MDG integration with SAP Joule, our generic copilot, which is always available for SAP users, regardless which process they are currently working in. Now, every business user can look up existing business partners in the system from their current work context. They just open the copilot in the side bar and start a chat in natural language, while SAP Joule guides them through a dialogue. If a user decides that changes to a business partner are needed, SAP Joule can take him or her to the right MDG user interface to carry out or trigger the changes.

Planned innovation: enhanced business partner governance in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Now let's come to some planned innovations. Again, the graphic in the top-right corner shows how these relate to our vision. As you can see, this is related to modularization and the cloud.

Later this year, we plan to enhance the capabilities for the governance for business partner master data on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. On our way to leveraging cloud-ready mode in all MDG product versions, we will also use this mode in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to have a common development base for the MDG key capabilities. Cloud-ready mode in MDG was already introduced in SAP Master Data Governance, cloud edition in 2021 and in SAP MDG on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition in 2023.

This covers the processes for central governance – including inbound processing that triggers governance processes. It includes data provider integration with CDQ, as well as data quality management with validations and enrichment, and more.

For our customers on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, this means they can introduce governance and control of the creation and change processes for business partner data, and they can increase effectiveness in the management of business partner data. As mentioned earlier, the focus now is on business partner data, further master data domains are planned for later – next in line is the product domain.

Planned innovation: processing business partner using SAP Joule

One more planned innovation that I would like to introduce also relates to AI. The recent innovation involving SAP Joule integration that I explained earlier was more about finding existing business partners or triggering changes by taking the user to the MDG user interface. We plan to expand this Joule dialog, so that the users can do even more without having to leave their work context.

With the planned innovation shown in the graphic above, business users can not only ask SAP Joule to search or display business partner data, but also use the AI copilot when it comes to changing or creating business partner data using natural language, without leaving their current tasks and without having to have any MDG expertise. They describe, in natural language, what master data changes they would like to initiate, and SAP Joule will guide them through a complete dialogue, and ultimately trigger the request for changes in the background. That way, every business user can seamlessly participate in master data processing, enhancing the effectiveness, speed, and automation of business partner governance. Instead of unstructured requests being sent to your master data team, who then has to enter these into the system, business users will now be supported by SAP Joule to provide structured input that only needs to be enriched and validated by the experts. And even those tasks can be largely automated by MDG through automatic derivations and validations. 

 Snapshot of MDG roadmap

 

Finally, here is an overview of all the innovations that we have planned for the next few years. All this information is also available in the SAP Roadmap Explorer. This slide reads from left to right, starting with recent innovations on the left-hand side and showing the planned innovations for 2025 and beyond. 

I know that this might look a bit of an eye chart, so I recommend taking a closer look at the Roadmap Explorer. For now, I have highlighted some of the most important planned innovations in a larger font:

Innovation highlights

When it comes to summarizing the innovation highlights, I have already mentioned the scenarios for AI that we already provided. We also provided innovations around data quality analytics in SAP Analytics Cloud, reference data processes and derivation scenarios.

With regards to the innovation highlights planned further up on the road, I already mentioned our plan to enable all relevant MDG processes for business partner data on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Version. So far, we have offered that full functionality on SAP S/4HANA only for on-premise and private cloud deployments.

In addition, we intend to focus a lot on the product domain, which includes the cloud-ready mode architecture across all versions of MDG.

In parallel, we are working on further platform capabilities, like providing SAP Master Data Governance, cloud edition on SAP BTP also as Platform-as-a-Service (currently, it is offered as Software-as-a-Service) and providing the cloud-ready mode option also for custom-defined objects.

In addition, there are all the other planned innovations shown in the background of the graphic that you can check out in detail in the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

SAP Master Data Governance in a nutshell

To summarize, SAP Master Data Governance is the one solution for your entire enterprise master data management program. It is an application that provides preconfigured, domain-specific master data governance. At the same time, it is an open platform to extend and build, in order to manage your own master data domains for all SAP and non-SAP landscapes.

MDG is also a key enabler that will help you get ready for your future business transformations. Many things are already available today, but we also discussed all the innovations on our roadmap for MDG that follow our main themes of automation, and federation to enable our customers’ digital transformation and their path to the cloud. Our roadmap for MDG will focus on unlocking these additional benefits for our customers, while SAP’s Business Suite vision continues to allow us to do more than just provide a toolbox for master data management.

To stay on track with what's going on in SAP MDG, simply follow the SAP Community Topic Page for SAP Master Data Governance and join the Q&A and discussion forum.

Best,
Markus

entry.title: Reimagining SAP MDG Field Validations Low-Code Approach | UI Field Control Made Dynamic Yet Simple !
entry.content:
Overview

Working with SAP MDG (Master Data Governance) often means balancing two realities: robust governance and agile adaptability. One of the common we face during MDG implementation is managing field validations with user-friendly alerts.

Whether a field should be hidden, mandatory or optional often depends on multiple factors like CR type, entity, company code or user role etc. Traditionally, these validations are implemented via BRF+ expressions, Enhancements in feeder classes, Hard-coded logic in the UI layer/BAdIs.

The Problem: Code Dependency in Field Validation

MDG validations are crucial for maintaining clean and consistent master data. However, the standard methods come with limitations & most teams rely on:

  • Feeder class logic: Feeder class enhancements require ABAP expertise and testing cycles.
  • UI rule maintenance is scattered and often difficult to track.
  • BRF+ rules or hardcoded validations code: Every new business scenario (e.g. different behaviour based on company code or region) means new logic and testing.
  • No centralized view of how validations are controlled across the application.

- While these are functional, they’re rigid, developer-dependent, and non-scalable. This complexity makes it difficult for functional/ business teams to adapt validations quickly and every change creates a dependency on development teams reducing agility.

Challenges: Too Much Code, Too Little Agility
  • Hide/Show fields based on Role UI logic  is non-transparent.
  • Maintain field rules over time - Static logic -No visibility for business teams.
  • The key pain point: Every small validation change turns into a development cycle.

- But what if we could avoid coding and development cycle every time specially for simple level properties or validations, yet still provide fully dynamic, context-sensitive field behaviour.

Solution: Rule the Config-Driven Field Validation Framework [ All In One Place]

To address these challenges, a custom configuration table was designed to serve as a central validation engine covers easy level validations. Field behaviour across various MDG entities and scenarios was defined through this table eliminating the need for code changes every time.

- These rules are consumed at runtime ensuring the UI responds dynamically based on master data context.

- Validation Types : M = Mandatory, O = Optional, H = Hidden, R = Read Only

- This table is maintained via a simple maintenance view or SM30 transaction/T-Code assigned to TMG accessible to key users or functional consultants.

All this happens without modifying feeder classes or enhancing the UI every time.

Benefits of This Approach
  • No More Coding: New validation rules don’t require any ABAP changes at-least for simple validations.
  • Business Empowerment: Functional/Business teams can maintain rules via a user-friendly view.
  • Central Governance: One place to view and manage all field control rules along with by whom & when it’s added or changed.
  • Audit-friendly: clearly see why and when a rule applies.
  • No BRF+ overload: clean separation of decision logic.
  • Faster Change Cycles: No transports or regression testing required for every new validation rule.
  • Scalable to all MDG domains MDG – S,M,C (Supplier, Material, Customer)
Real Impact
  • After rollout: Reduced ~70% of validation-related change requests.
  • Built an enterprise-grade, reusable framework used across modules.
  • Delivered faster time-to-compliance for changing regulatory/market needs.
  • It's a shift from “write code to validate” ➝ to “configure to adapt”
How It Works: Plug-In Logic, Zero Enhancement for later changes
  1. Custom Table is maintained in SM30 or Z/Y T-code (or via custom UI).
  2. Lightweight enhancement logic is added once to retrieve rules based on runtime values.
  3. The UI behaviour adjusts: field becomes hidden, read-only mandatory or optional.
  4. No need to touch feeder classes again & ever.
You can even combine this with:
  • Workflow context (field is mandatory only in approval steps)
  • User or Role-level personalization (validation based on user group)
  • For multiple conditions can add different Sr. No conditions. E.g. Department is mandatory for Company Code =  ‘0001’  & '0005', So Can add two records with different Sr. No.
Requirement - For CR Type: ZCCT1P2: Create Cost Center with Hry. Assignments:
  1.    Business Area to be hidden.
  2.    Profit Center is mandatory.
  3.    Department is mandatory for Company Code =  ‘0001’
  4.    User Responsible is mandatory for cost center category = ‘%’.
Implementation

[ Fig. 1.0. Table Contents ]

  • ZCCT1P2: Create Cost Center with Hry. Assignments.
  • Step ‘0’ defines Requestor Level.
  • Tech Property  & Conditional Tech-Property stores technical attributes.
  • Table also contains audit columns to track changes.
  1. BAdI: USMD_ACC_FLD_PROP_CUST_DEP_SET
  • EI: ZFI_ES_MDG_FLD_PROP
  • BAdI Implementation: ZFI_MDG_FLD_PROP
  • Class: ZCL_FI_MDG_FLD_PROP
  • Method: IF_EX_USMD_ACC_FLD_PROP_CDS~MODIFY_FLD_PROP_ATTR
  METHOD if_ex_usmd_acc_fld_prop_cds~modify_fld_prop_attr.

    DATA:lr_model TYPE REF TO if_usmd_app_context.
    CALL METHOD cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context
      RECEIVING
        eo_context = lr_model.
    IF lr_model IS BOUND.
      CALL METHOD lr_model->get_attributes
        IMPORTING
          ev_crequest_type = DATA(lv_cr_type)
          ev_crequest_step = DATA(lv_cr_step).
    ENDIF.

    DATA: go_tab_descr   TYPE REF TO cl_abap_tabledescr,
          go_struc_descr TYPE REF TO cl_abap_structdescr,
          lt_components  TYPE abap_component_tab.
    DATA: name_range TYPE RANGE OF zfi_mdg_valt-condition_tech.

    "Pre-Exception Handling To Get Valid Fields For it_data As not-valid entry entered in Condition Property
    go_tab_descr ?= cl_abap_tabledescr=>describe_by_data( it_data ).
    CHECK sy-subrc = 0.
    go_struc_descr ?= go_tab_descr->get_table_line_type( ). "Get the structure of your internal table
    lt_components  = go_struc_descr->get_components( ).
    REFRESH name_range.
    name_range = VALUE #( FOR wa IN lt_components ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = wa-name ) ).

    "Check Mandatory(*)/Hide/Read Only/Optional Attribute Property
    SELECT * FROM zfi_mdg_valt INTO TABLE (it_mdg_val)
          WHERE cr_type = _cr_type AND cr_step = _cr_step AND entity_type = _entity
          AND zmodule = '0G' AND active = 'X'.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.

      LOOP AT ct_fld_prop ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_data_2>).
        ASSIGN COMPONENT 'USMD_FP' OF STRUCTURE <fs_data_2> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_fld_prop_2>).

        LOOP AT it_mdg_val INTO DATA(wa_val) WHERE entity_type = iv_entity. "Traverse Custom Defined Properties

          IF wa_val-condition_tech IS NOT INITIAL. "Check If Condition maintained or free of any condition
            IF  wa_val-condition_tech IN name_range.    "Preventive Action
              READ TABLE it_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_data_con>)
              WITH KEY (wa_val-condition_tech) = wa_val-condition_val.
              "Condition is not matching, continue with next iteration of properties of it_mdg_val
              IF sy-subrc NE 0.
                CONTINUE.
              ENDIF.
            ELSE.
              CONTINUE.   "Not Valid Condition Attribute/Property
            ENDIF.
          ENDIF.

          "Check for further tech property
          ASSIGN COMPONENT wa_val-tech_name OF STRUCTURE <fs_fld_prop_2> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_field_2>).
          IF <ls_field_2> IS ASSIGNED.
            <ls_field_2> = wa_val-property.
          ENDIF.
          UNASSIGN  <ls_field_2>.
        ENDLOOP.

        UNASSIGN <fs_fld_prop_2>.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.
       2.  BAdI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE
  • EI: ZFI_ES_MDG_VAL
  • BAdI Implementation: ZFI_MDG_VAL
  • Class: ZCL_FI_MDG_VAL
  • Method: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY
  METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.

    DATA: lr_model   TYPE REF TO if_usmd_app_context.
    DATA: go_tab_descr   TYPE REF TO cl_abap_tabledescr,
          go_struc_descr TYPE REF TO cl_abap_structdescr,
          lt_components  TYPE abap_component_tab.
    DATA: name_range TYPE RANGE OF zfi_mdg_valt-condition_tech.

    CALL METHOD cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context
      RECEIVING
        eo_context = lr_model.
    IF lr_model IS BOUND.
      CALL METHOD lr_model->get_attributes
        IMPORTING
          ev_crequest_type = DATA(lv_cr_type)
          ev_crequest_step = DATA(lv_cr_step).
    ENDIF.

    "Pre-Exception Handling To Get Valid Fields For it_data As not-valid entry entered in Condition Property
    go_tab_descr ?= cl_abap_tabledescr=>describe_by_data( it_data ).
    CHECK sy-subrc = 0.
    go_struc_descr ?= go_tab_descr->get_table_line_type( ). "Get the structure of your internal table
    lt_components  = go_struc_descr->get_components( ).
    REFRESH name_range.
    name_range = VALUE #( FOR wa IN lt_components ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = wa-name ) ).

    "Mandatory Check Working for FI : GL,CC,PC
    SELECT * FROM zfi_mdg_valt INTO TABLE (it_zfi_mdg_valderv)
      WHERE cr_type = _cr_type AND cr_step = _cr_step
      AND zmodule = '0G' AND property = 'M' AND active = 'X'.

    LOOP AT it_zfi_mdg_valderv INTO DATA(wa_val).
      LOOP AT it_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_data>).
        IF <ls_data> IS ASSIGNED.

          IF wa_val-condition_tech IS NOT INITIAL. "Check If Condition maintained or free of any condition
            IF  wa_val-condition_tech IN name_range.    "Preventive Action

              ASSIGN COMPONENT wa_val-condition_tech OF STRUCTURE <ls_data> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_con>).
              IF <ls_con> IS ASSIGNED AND <ls_con> IS NOT INITIAL.
                IF <ls_con> NE wa_val-condition_val.
                  CONTINUE.
                ENDIF.
                UNASSIGN <ls_con>.
              ENDIF.

            ELSE.
              APPEND VALUE #( msgty = 'E' msgv1 = 'Please check entity name' msgv2 = wa_val-condition_tech   ) TO et_message.
              CONTINUE.
              "msgid = 'zfi_mdg_message'  msgno = 000
            ENDIF.
          ENDIF.

          ASSIGN COMPONENT wa_val-tech_name OF STRUCTURE <ls_data> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_value>).
          IF <ls_value> IS ASSIGNED AND <ls_value> IS INITIAL.
            APPEND VALUE #( msgid = wa_val-msgid msgty = wa_val-msgty
            msgno = wa_val-msgno msgv1 = wa_val-msgv1 msgv2 = wa_val-msgv2 ) TO et_message.
            UNASSIGN <ls_value>.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.

      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.


  ENDMETHOD.
Output
  1. Scenario I

       1.1. With Loading, Business area is hidden, Profit Center is mandatory, Department & User Responsible are not mandatory.

[ Fig 1.1 : Initial Screen ]

1.2.  With entering Company code = ‘0001’, Department becomes mandatory (*).

[ Fig 1.2 : Department is mandatory ]

2. Scenario II

2.1. For Company code = ‘0003’, Department is not mandatory

[ Fig 2.1 : Department not mandatory ]

3. Scenario III

3.1. With loading, User Responsible is not mandatory by default.

[ Fig 3.1 : User Responsible not mandatory ]

3.2. With Cost center category = ‘%’, User Responsible becomes mandatory.

[ Fig 3.2 : User Responsible mandatory ]

3.3. Click on Check: As Profit Center & User Responsible are blank, we got error messages defined in our Z table.

[ Fig 3.3 : Messages ]

3.4.Errors on Check

[ Fig 3.4 : Messages ]

4. Additional Sanity Check:

To troubleshoot scenario where user has maintained conditional-tech-property/attribute as not-valid property value ( By mistake ; ) So below error will appear on hitting Check.

As we are using this conditional-tech-property to read IT_DATA, it’s safe idea to check pre-hand whether the property is valid and actually present in IT_DATA to refrain from last moment surprises. (or technically a dump ; )

[ Fig. 4.1. Preventive Code ]

[ Fig : 4.2. conditional tech attribute = ‘CCODECCTR1’ is not valid attribute of data model ]

5. Message Class: Generic 000, So No transport required every time for new messages.

[ Fig : 5 Message Class ]

Conclusion

- SAP MDG is built to empower governed, agile master data. But flexibility shouldn’t mean fragility. With a configurable validation engine, we’ve transformed how we think about field behavior turning a developer-led task into a business-led control mechanism and maximum governance.

Thanks !

entry.title: Bringing CDQ to SAP MDG Classic Mode: Enabling Trusted Business Partner Creation with Custom DPI
entry.content:
Executive Summary

SAP MDG classic mode does not support standard DPI integration with CDQ, leaving master data stewards without access to trusted external sources during BP creation.

This blog demonstrates a custom solution that simulates DPI behavior using REST APIs and Custom List UIBB — enabling real-time Business Partner lookup from CDQ inside the Change Request UI. The result is streamlined data entry, improved data accuracy, and more efficient onboarding — even in SAP S/4HANA 2023 (on-premise, classic mode) or earlier versions.

 

Introduction

Creating trusted and error-free business partner records is a critical goal in business. This article explores an approach to achieve that goal by integrating CDQ reference data in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) classic mode.

SAP introduced Data Provider Integration (DPI) with CDQ AG as a cloud platform, allowing master data stewards to source high-quality business partner data directly from authoritative reference sources. Initially delivered in SAP MDG, cloud edition, this functionality is also available in SAP S/4HANA 2023 under cloud-ready mode.

However, since this out-of-the-box DPI integration is only available in cloud-ready mode on SAP S/4HANA 2023, it creates a functional gap for systems running in classic mode (SAP S/4HANA 2023) as well as for earlier S/4HANA versions.

To bridge this gap and enable external data usage during business partner creation, a custom implementation is needed. This article introduces a solution where CDQ-sourced business partner suggestions are presented dynamically in a Custom List UIBB within the MDG Change Request UI, based on input fields like organization name, address, and tax number.

 

Background

Corporate Data Quality (CDQ) is a cloud-based platform that provides verified company information by connecting to official and commercial registers globally. It allows organizations to source high-quality reference data—such as legal names, addresses, tax numbers, and registration details—during master data creation.

SAP has extended its existing DPI framework to include CDQ as an out-of-the-box data provider, enabling plug-and-play access to trusted business partner data. This is available in:

  • SAP Master Data Governance, cloud edition
  • SAP S/4HANA 2023 (cloud-ready mode)


Figure 1 – Technical view of Data Provider Integration with CDQ

Through this integration, master data stewards can search for business entities directly within the Manage Business Partners Fiori Application, retrieve verified information in real-time, and auto-fill business partner fields. This streamlines onboarding processes, improves data accuracy, and reduces manual maintenance effort.


Figure 2 – Data Provider Integration supporting automation in creation and change of business partner data

For details about DPI, see this SAP Blog.

 

The Limitation: No CDQ DPI in Classic Mode

While the CDQ integration via DPI delivers a streamlined way to source verified business partner data, its standard implementation is currently limited to SAP MDG cloud edition and SAP S/4HANA 2023 (cloud-ready mode). This presents a challenge for organizations using MDG in classic mode or on earlier S/4HANA versions, where the standard DPI configuration and Fiori-based integration are not available.

In such environments, master data stewards often resort to manual data entry, untrusted external sources, increasing the risk of incomplete, inconsistent records—precisely the issues CDQ is meant to solve.

The core challenge becomes:
How can CDQ reference data be leveraged within MDG classic mode, aligning with its Change Request-driven process, even when the standard DPI usage is not supported?

 

Feasible Option - Abstract

The solution presented in this article addresses that challenge by integrating CDQ through a DPI-based approach, enabling real-time access to external data within the MDG classic mode’s Change Request UI using a Custom List UIBB.


Figure 3 – An example screenshot of a Change Request with Custom List UIBB

In this example, the master data steward begins by entering basic input values—e.g., Name 1 and Country/Region—in the Business Partner Details section of the Change Request. As shown in Figure 3, once the user enters Name 1 and Country/Region, the Custom “BP Lookup” List UIBB fetches relevant business partner suggestions from CDQ dynamically.

After selecting the appropriate CDQ-sourced record, the data is transferred into the related sections, as illustrated in Figures 4 and 5.


Figure 4 – Transferred BP Details data retrieved from CDQ into Change Request UI


Figure 5 – Transferred Tax Number data retrieved from CDQ into Change Request UI

 

Some Nice-To-Have Skills

Here are some nice-to-have skills and knowledge areas for handling this topic:

ABAP programming, T-Code: SM59, SM30, STRUST, Cross-Badi derivation, Overview Page Floorplan (OVP), REST API, RFC, MDG

 

Solution in a Nutshell

The solution enables real-time use of CDQ reference data within the SAP MDG Change Request UI through a Custom List UIBB.

As users fill in key fields, such as organization name and/or address, the system fetches potential business partner records from CDQ. The list is updated automatically whenever any parameter is changed. With a single click on ‘Transfer Values’, selected CDQ data is populated into the corresponding MDG fields.

 

Implementation Steps

For our solution, we pursued the following steps:

  • Create an API Key Instance from CDQ with a Client ID and Client Secret. For more information, please visit this site.
  • Import TLS root certificate for https://api.cdq.com. For more information, check out this blog.
  • Maintain the required RFC Destinations to set up technical communication.
  • Determine the logical port as the DPI’s general RFC Destination. Configure the V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST view in SM30.
  • Create these classes to implement the logic;
    1. API Caller Class (ZCL_CDQ_API_CALLER) -> Handling API requests, communicating with CDQ
    2. Main Integration Class (ZCL_CDQ_BP_INTEGRATION) -> Prepare the request data and map the response of the API to the UIBB format
    3. Feeder Class of Custom List UIBB (ZCL_BP_GUIBB_CDQ_FEEDER) -> Maintain the data
    4. Derivation Class (ZCL_BP_CDQ_DERIVATION) -> Populate the related fields with the selected row
    5. Utilities Class (ZCL_BP_CDQ_UTILITIES) -> Collect useful methods that are used several times
  • Add a Custom List UIBB into BS_BP_ALL_OVP.

Create New API Key;


Figure 6 – Generating API Key from CDQ Portal for Secure Integration

To establish secure HTTPS communication with CDQ, the certificate for api.cdq.com must be imported via transaction STRUST. This is depicted in Figure 7, where the certificate is added under the SSL Client (Standard);


Figure 7 – Certification for CDQ API

Set up External Server HTTP Connections;


Figure 8 – RFC Connections for CDQ

The created RFC Destination Z_DPI_CDQ is assigned as the logical port for DPI’s general operation. You can see this configuration in Figure 9, which shows the entry in the V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST view;


Figure 9 – Data entry for V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST to determine logical port for general DPI operations

Remark: The following methods will be the main part of the framework, they do not include the whole picture.

The method responsible for communicating with CDQ (ZCL_CDQ_API_CALLER->CALL_API);

  METHOD call_api.

    TRY.
        DATA(rfc_destination) = get_rfc_destination( if_mdqdpi_rfc_dest_constants=>provider-cdq-operation-general-name ).

        IF rest_client IS NOT BOUND.
          DATA(http_client) = get_http_client( rfc_destination ).

          cl_http_utility=>set_request_uri( request = http_client->request
                                            uri     = api_path ).

          rest_client = NEW cl_rest_http_client( http_client ).
        ENDIF.

      CATCH cx_mdqdpi_functional_error.
        rfc_destination = get_rfc_destination( if_mdqdpi_rfc_dest_constants=>provider-cdq-operation-lookup-name ).
        IF rest_client IS NOT BOUND.
          http_client = get_http_client( rfc_destination ).
          rest_client = NEW cl_rest_http_client( http_client ).
        ENDIF.
        IF rest_client IS INITIAL.
          RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_mdqdpi_functional_error( textid = cx_mdqdpi_functional_error=>data_provider_setup_error ).
        ENDIF.
    ENDTRY.

    DATA(request) = build_request( payload = payload
                                   mapping = mapping ).
    rest_client->post( request ).
    result = rest_client->get_response_entity( )->get_string_data( ).
    analyze_response(
      EXPORTING
        string_response  = result
        rest_client      = rest_client                 " REST Client
      IMPORTING
        http_status_code = http_status_code
    ).

    rest_client->close( ).
    CLEAR rest_client.

  ENDMETHOD.

The method responsible for preparing the API response for Custom List UIBB (ZCL_CDQ_BP_INTEGRATION->BP_LOOK_UP);

  METHOD bp_look_up.

    DATA:
      ls_abap_format  TYPE zif_cdq_bp_integration=>gty_look_up_response,
      ls_t100_message TYPE scx_t100key.

    CLEAR:
      ev_http_status_code,
      es_cdq_golden_output,
      et_cdq_output,
      et_t100_message.

    DATA(api_caller) = zcl_cdq_api_caller=>get_instance( ).

    DATA(payload) = prepare_bp_look_up_request(
      EXPORTING
        is_cdq_attr = is_cdq_attr                 " Type for ~ BP Lookup
    ).

    TRY.
        api_caller->call_api(
          EXPORTING
            api_path         = '/sap-odm/v3/referencedata/rest/v3/businesspartners/lookup'
            payload          = payload
          IMPORTING
            result           = DATA(http_response)
            http_status_code = ev_http_status_code
        ).

      CATCH cx_mdqdpi_functional_error INTO DATA(lx_error).

*     General error message info
        CLEAR ls_t100_message.
        ls_t100_message = lx_error->if_t100_message~t100key.
        go_bp_cdq_utilities->prepare_t100_message(
          EXPORTING
            ix_error        = lx_error                 " Functional Errors
          CHANGING
            cs_t100_message = ls_t100_message                 " T100
        ).
        IF ls_t100_message IS NOT INITIAL.
          APPEND ls_t100_message TO et_t100_message.
        ENDIF.

*     Detailed error message info if it exists
        IF lx_error->previous IS NOT INITIAL.
          CLEAR ls_t100_message.
          DATA(lx_previos_error) = CAST cx_mdqdpi_functional_error( lx_error->previous ).
          ls_t100_message = lx_previos_error->if_t100_message~t100key.
          go_bp_cdq_utilities->prepare_t100_message(
            EXPORTING
              ix_error        = lx_previos_error                 " Functional Errors
            CHANGING
              cs_t100_message = ls_t100_message                 " T100
          ).
          IF ls_t100_message IS NOT INITIAL.
            APPEND ls_t100_message TO et_t100_message.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.
        EXIT.
    ENDTRY.

    convert_to_abap_format(
      EXPORTING
        iv_data_in_json_format = http_response
        iv_api_type            = 'LOOK_UP'                 " LOOK_UP / BANK_REL / EMAIL
      IMPORTING
        es_look_up_response    = ls_abap_format                 " BP Lookup Response Type
    ).

    convert_to_uibb_format(
      EXPORTING
        is_abap_format       = ls_abap_format
      IMPORTING
        es_cdq_golden_output = es_cdq_golden_output                 " Type for ~ BP Lookup
        et_cdq_output        = et_cdq_output                 " Table Type for ~ BP Lookup
    ).

  ENDMETHOD.

Create a Custom List UIBB to maintain trusted business partner data in Change Request UI;


Figure 10 – Custom List UIBB Component Configuration

 

Conclusion

This solution demonstrates how trusted CDQ reference data can be leveraged in SAP MDG classic mode through a custom DPI-inspired approach. By integrating REST-based API logic into a Custom List UIBB inside the Change Request UI, users can enrich business partner master data in real-time. This makes the solution ideal for on-premise S/4HANA systems aiming to improve data accuracy and reduce manual effort.

entry.title: SAP MDG: How to restrict not req. document type in SAP MDG Change Request (Customer/Supplier) UI?
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Note: I didn't add Change Request UI Screenshots.

Faced the Problem:
Configured some Z Document Types. While choosing document types while creating of Change request (It usually displays Custom + Standard Document Types) but i don't want to display standard document types. 

How to solve the problem:
please find below process to clear the faced problem 🙂

Go to the below navigation:
SPRO > Cross-Application Components > Document Management > Control Data > Define DMS Document Types.

Choose the document type & go to the navigation—Define Object Links. Choose the LFA1 & delete it.

As it should not show for the supplier change request.

SAP Master Data Governance 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: SAP MDG: Custom Generic Class for developments
entry.content:
HI SCN Folks, 

Note:
01. There are several ways to implement it, and the blog that's written is one of the ways.
02. There are no screenshots attached related to SAP Logon & SAP MDG UI Screens.
03. In this blog, example which i taken the development of one of the Enhancement UIBB & a Method is GET_DATA.

Faced Problem:
Every time i used to call the below program for different placeholders & for different requirements. In short, making use of the same code again & again.

ZSU_MDG_CL_ENH_CUS_UIBB

DATA :
  lv_cr_number TYPE usmd_crequest,
  lv_crtype    TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
  lv_process   TYPE usmd_process.

DATA(lo_context) = cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context( ).

IF lo_context IS BOUND.
  CALL METHOD lo_context->get_attributes
    IMPORTING
      ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
      ev_crequest_type = lv_crtype
      ev_process       = lv_process.
ENDIF.

IF lv_crtype EQ 'ZSUCRTYPE'.

      "Requirement Logic

ENDIF.

How to reduce this reusability? Please follow the below process

01. Create one custom class.
       ZSU_MDG_CL_GENERIC (Class)

02. Create one Static Method (Level), Public (Visibility) & Exporting Parameters.
        GET_CR_RELATED

  class-methods GET_CR_RELATED
    exporting
      !EO_MODEL type ref to IF_USMD_MODEL_EXT
      !EV_PARENT_PROCESS type USMD_PROCESS
      !EV_PROCESS type USMD_PROCESS
      !EV_WI_ID type SWW_WIID
      !EV_CREQUEST_ID type USMD_CREQUEST
      !EV_CREQUEST_TYPE type USMD_CREQUEST_TYPE
      !EV_CREQUEST_STEP type USMD_CREQUEST_APPSTEP
      !EV_CREQUEST_INDEX type USMD_CREQUEST_WFINDEX
      !EV_EDITION type USMD_EDITION
      !EV_OTC type USMD_OTC .


03. Now enter the below code in the method (Source Code). 

  method GET_CR_RELATED.

      DATA:
      lo_app_ctxt  TYPE REF TO  if_usmd_app_context.


    lo_app_ctxt = cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context( ).

    IF lo_app_ctxt IS BOUND.

      lo_app_ctxt->get_attributes(
       IMPORTING
         eo_model          =  eo_model
         ev_process        =  ev_process
         ev_wi_id          =  ev_wi_id
         ev_crequest_id    =  ev_crequest_id
         ev_crequest_type  =  ev_crequest_type
         ev_crequest_step  =  ev_crequest_step
         ev_crequest_index =  ev_crequest_index
         ev_otc            =  ev_otc
     ).
    ENDIF.

  endmethod.

Done with part of this class (ZSU_MDG_CL_GENERIC). 

Now It's time to use it in any development placeholder; in this blog, implementing it in (ZSU_MDG_CL_ENH_CUS_UIBB).

  DATA: lv_creq_type TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
          lv_wf_step   TYPE usmd_crequest_appstep.


    CALL METHOD ZSU_MDG_CL_GENERIC=>get_cr_related
      IMPORTING
        ev_crequest_type = lv_creq_type  " Type of Change Request
        ev_crequest_step = lv_wf_step.

IF lv_crtype EQ 'ZSUCRTYPE'.
       IF lv_wf_step = '00'.

      "Requirement Logic

ENDIF.
ENDIF.

 

SAP Master Data Governance 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Why Event-Enabling MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh is a Game Changer
entry.content:
Why Event-Enabling MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh is a Game Changer 

Introduction 

It is rare today to see a large enterprise with a monolithic system landscape; enterprises today target best of class solutions to meet the requirements of their business users, suppliers and customers.  This ever-growing landscape of heterogenous solutions increases the burden placed on integration tooling to keep their records and transactions in sync.  Lack of a true enterprise mesh to connect these applications will lead:  

  • Missing or duplicate records 
  • Data silos 
  • Out of Sync Records 
  • A fragmented view of business 

All of this will create a disjointed view of the business. Master data management is a critical function for any enterprise and requires strong coordination between business stakeholders and the IT teams that own and manage the solutions for master data.   

In today’s rapidly evolving digital landscape, data is only as powerful as its timeliness and accuracy. For organizations relying on SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to manage core business objects like Business Partners, Materials, and Cost Centers, the need for real-time data propagation across systems is more critical than ever. Traditional integration approaches often rely on batch jobs or synchronous APIs that are fragile, tightly coupled, and reactive. 

This is where event-enabling MDG—using SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) with the Event Enablement Add-On—changes the game. By embracing Event-Driven Architecture (EDA), organizations can deliver real-time, loosely coupled, and scalable master data integration across the entire business landscape.  

A study by Aberdeen research showed that 66% of organizations do not have an IT environment that is cutting edge and built to support their needs around master data integration.  What held these organizations back was:  

  • Data growing at a faster rate than they could manage and analyze it  
  • There was strong difficulty sharing and accessing data across business areas  
  • Lack of IT resources to support the growing integration needs around master data integration 

 

However, enterprises that operate in a best-in-class strategy for master data management and integration see across the board improvement in operating profit, total customer base, revenue and employee retention. 

 

Why Event-Enable MDG System? 

SAP MDG is the single source of truth for enterprise master data, but its ability to share validated changes quickly and reliably across consuming systems is key to maximizing its value. 

Challenges with traditional MDG integration: 

  • A complex spider of point-to-point synchronous integrations that require a high level of development effort for any update or change 
  • Data is out sync due to legacy methods of integration such as batch file transfer  
  • Rapidly growing system landscape new systems being onboarded all with their own methodologies for sending and receiving data  
  • Lack of a centralized view to find catalogs of master data events within the enterprise  

Event-enabling MDG solves this by: 

  • New systems can rapidly be onboarded to consume master data events without disrupting the existing integrations 
  • Organizations can easily create an event catalogue to find and filter master data events relevant to their system  
  • Point to point connections can be eliminated by adopting an event driven asynchronous architecture allowing for decoupling of all downstream systems 
  • Events can be filtered allowing downstream systems to be notified only of events they care about 
  • Updates are pushed in real time to all downstream systems when an object is created or modified  

Key Use Cases & Benefiting Systems 

Real-world scenarios where event-enabling MDG unlocks high business value 

  • Material Master Synchronization 
  • Updates to Material data in MDG can trigger: 
  • Automatic replication to production planning systems 
  • Real-time updates to supplier catalogs or inventory platforms 
  • Notifications to product lifecycle or quality teams 
  • Sync updated UPCs/EANs to all subscribing systems in real time to eliminate product returns resulting from inaccurate product data or goods not being sold at check-out due to missed scans  
  • Business Partner Integration 
  • When a Business Partner is created or updated in MDG, an event can trigger updates in: 
  • S/4HANA core and satellite systems 
  • Customer portals and CRMs (e.g., Salesforce) 
  • Identity & Access Management tools (e.g., Azure AD, Okta) 
  • Global trade systems or compliance platforms 
  • Sync updates to Business Partner information to all subscribing systems in real time to eliminate issues with wrong, outdated or missing sold to and ship to information causing delays in orders, extra shipping costs and low customer satisfaction  
  • Cost Center & Financial Master Data Distribution 
  • Replicate Cost Center changes to subscribing systems in real time such as third-party HR, External Talent Management, Manufacturing Execution Systems, Travel and Expense systems to keep accounting data current and accurate 
  • Ease the pain during mergers and acquisitions in distributing changes to chart of account information to all subscribing systems enabling consistent financial reporting 

 

 

Benefits of Using SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh with Event Add-On for MDG Integration 

The Event Enablement Add-On for MDG simplifies the process of turning master data changes into standardized events that are automatically published to SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh. 

Benefits: 

  • Automatic Event Generation 

The add-on captures and publishes master data changes as events without requiring custom coding. 

  • Seamless integration with AEM 

Events are routed through Advanced Event Mesh for real-time, reliable distribution across subscribing systems. 

  • Reduced Development Effort 

Accelerates event-driven master data integration projects by handling event creation and metadata management out of the box. 

  • Loosely Couple Architecture 

Consumers subscribe to relevant event topics without impacting MDG logic. 

  • Scalable & Resilient 

Built-in guaranteed delivery, replay, and fault tolerance via AEM. 

 

 

Extending Event-Driven Integration with SAP Integration Suite 

While SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh excels at delivering real-time events from SAP MDG & MDI, some integration scenarios require additional processing—such as data transformation, enrichment, or bridging to legacy systems that cannot consume events directly. 

SAP Integration Suite provides the ideal complement through lightweight micro-integrations (iFlows) that can handle these needs efficiently. This combined approach ensures enterprises benefit from the agility and scalability of event-driven architectures, while still addressing practical system integration requirements. 

 

Conclusion 

Event-enabling SAP MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh represents a significant leap toward real-time, intelligent master data distribution. It enables enterprises to respond faster, integrate smarter, and govern better, all while reducing integration maintenance costs. 

If you're looking to modernize how your organization distributes critical master data, it's time to move from point-to-point to event-driven. Let’s start the conversation! 

Blog Authors:  

 

 

Sumeet Koshal - Solace  

Director of EDA Solutions North America  

connect on linked in  

 

 

Cooper Walsh - SAP 

Sr. Solutions Advisor - SAP BTP 

connect on linked in

entry.title: SAP MDG: Making CR Descriptions Auto-Populated and Read-Only
entry.content:
HI SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Introduction

In SAP Master Data Governance (MDG), whenever you create, change, or extend master data such as Customer, Supplier, or Material, you start by choosing a Change Request (CR) Type. Once the CR Type is selected, the system opens the Change Request screen, where the Description field is mandatory and must be filled in manually.

While this works, it often leads to inconsistent naming conventions, typos, or missing context—especially in large teams. A better approach is to automatically populate the CR Description based on the CR Type and Data Model and make it read-only so that users can’t change it. This ensures standardization, saves time, and reduces errors.

Why Automate the CR Description?

  • Consistency: Every CR of the same type follows the same naming convention.

  • Efficiency: Users don’t waste time typing repetitive descriptions.

  • Accuracy: Eliminates human errors such as spelling mistakes or incomplete descriptions.

  • Governance: Locks the field to ensure compliance with naming rules.

The Requirement

We want the system to:

  1. Detect the CR Type and Data Model when a CR is created.

  2. Automatically fill in the Description based on these values.

  3. Make the field read-only so it cannot be manually edited.

Example:

CR Type Data Model Auto Description
ZMAT01MM"Material Creation Request"
ZCUST01BP"Customer Creation Request"
ZSUPP02BP"Supplier Extension Request"

Technical Implementation

We will achieve this using the BAdI USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGRATION.

1️⃣Create a BAdI Implementation

  • Go to transaction SE18 or SE19.

  • Create an implementation for the BAdI USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGRATION.

  • Choose the filter values for the relevant Data Model (e.g., BP, MM).

2️⃣Method to Auto-Populate the Description

Method:
IF_EX_USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGR~GET_CREQUEST_ATTRIBUTES

In this method, we will:

  • Read the Data Model (iv_model)

  • Read the CR Type (iv_crequest_type)

  • Set the Description (cv_description) accordingly

Sample Code:

METHOD if_ex_usmd_crequest_integr~get_crequest_attributes.

  IF iv_model = 'BP' AND iv_crequest_type = 'ZMDGCUS01'.
    cv_description = 'Create Customer'.   
                            
  ELSEIF iv_model = 'BP' AND iv_crequest_type = 'ZMDGSUP02'.
    cv_description = 'Change Supplier'.

  ELSEIF iv_model = 'MM' AND iv_crequest_type = 'ZMDGMAT03'.
    cv_description = 'Extend Material'.

  ENDIF.

ENDMETHOD.

 

3️⃣Method to Make the Field Read-Only

Method:
IF_EX_USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGR~GET_CREQUEST_FLD_PROP

Here, we change the field property so the Description field becomes Read-Only.

 Sample Code:

METHOD if_ex_usmd_crequest_integr~get_crequest_fld_prop.

  IF iv_model = 'BP' OR iv_model = 'MM'.
    cv_description_fld_prop = 'R'.  "R = Read-Only
  ENDIF.

ENDMETHOD.

 

4️⃣Transport & Test

  • Create a new CR for each CR Type & Data Model combination.

  • Verify that:

    • The Description is automatically filled.

    • The Description field is read-only.

After implementing the BAdI logic, we tested the functionality in SAP MDG to confirm that:

  1. The Description field is auto-populated based on the CR Type and Data Model.

  2. The Description field is read-only and cannot be manually edited.


Test Case Example

Scenario:

  • Data Model: BP

  • Change Request Type: ZMDGCUS01 (Customer Creation Request)

Expected Result:

  • Description auto-fills as "Customer Creation Request"

  • Field is non-editable

Actual Result: ✅ Working as expected

Screenshots from Testing

Before 

  • Description field is empty and requires manual entry

  • Field is editable

After

  • Description automatically filled with: Customer Creation Request

  • Field is locked (read-only)

Here’s your Before vs After comparison image. This will clearly show the difference after implementing.

 

Key Observations

  • Auto-filling eliminates manual typing errors

  • Read-only property ensures naming consistency

  • Enhancement works across different CR Types and Data Models defined in the BAdI logic

 

Conclusion

With just one BAdI implementation, you can make your SAP MDG CR descriptions consistent, accurate, and locked—improving user experience and enforcing governance standards. This small change saves time, avoids errors, and ensures that every CR is clearly described from the moment it’s created.

SAP Master Data Governance 


Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Event enabling SAP Data Replication Framework with Advanced Event Mesh & AIFAEM
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s interconnected enterprise landscape, real-time data movement and event-driven architectures are no longer optional—they are foundational. SAP offers a powerful trio of technologies to enable this: the SAP Data Replication Framework (DRF), SAP Integration Suite – Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), and the Application Interface Framework Event Mesh Add-On (AIFAEM).

SAPa Data Replication Framework (DRF)

The Data Replication Framework is a tool used to replicate master data accurately and efficiently across SAP and non-SAP systems, ensuring data consistency and integrity through various methods such as real-time replication, scheduled batch processing, and manual replication. It utilizes technologies such as SOAP or IDocs for asynchronous outbound services.

SAP Integration Suite – Advanced Event Mesh (AEM)

AEM is SAP’s enterprise-grade event broker that supports asynchronous, decoupled communication across distributed systems. It enables real-time event streaming, dynamic routing, and scalable integration across hybrid and multi-cloud environments. AEM supports open standards like CloudEvents and integrates with Kafka, REST, and MQTT, making it a versatile backbone for event-driven architectures.

AIFAEM – The Missing Link

To bridge traditional SAP systems like ECC or even S/4HANA with AEM, SAP introduced AIFAEM—an ABAP-based add-on that extends the Application Interface Framework (AIF). AIFAEM allows you to define and expose custom business events based on the BOR (Business Object Repository) framework. These events can then published to AEM in CloudEvents format, enabling seamless integration with modern event consumers.

AIFAEM supports:

  • Event creation from both ECC (SAP NW 7.31) and S/4HANA (SAP NW 7.55 and above)
  • CloudEvents formatting and structure mapping
  • Monitoring via SAP Fiori apps and transaction /AIF/ERR
  • Out-of-the-box connectivity to AEM without consuming AIF message quotas

Why This Matters

Together, DRF, AEM, and AIFAEM form a robust pipeline for event-driven data replication. DRF ensures the right data is selected and prepared, AIFAEM transforms it into events, and AEM distributes it across your enterprise landscape. This architecture empowers developers and architects to build responsive, scalable, and loosely coupled systems that are ready for the future of integration.

Disclaimer

The clean core approach for a connection between DRF and AEM, and I would recommend to apply this pattern, would be the Usage of a Standard DRF Replications provided by SAP which target an Iflow on Integration Suite (SOAP, XI or IDoc Sender Adapter) and pass the Event to AEM using the AEM Adapter. This would be a configuration only scenario and also can be monitored with SAP Application Interface Framework. 

The pattern explained in the following is bypassing the BTP Cloud Integration, AIFAEM is connecting directly to AEM. But since DRF does not support a REST connection, AIFAEM has to be involved and therefore a custom ABAP Class is required. Keep in mind that in my example the custom class is quite huge, because it is a copy of the Standard Business Partner Replication Class + adjustments for AIFAEM. Also for AIFAEM further custom objects are required (Action Function Module, custom DDIC objects).

 

How it works

1) DRF Customizing & Custom DRF Class

The Standard Object we are trying to use is 986 - Business Partner. You´ll find it in DRFIMG -> Enhance Default Settings for Outbound Implementations -> Define Business Objects

The corresponding Outbound Implementation (using the Standard SOAP Proxy ) is 986_3.

Since we don´t want to use SOAP, but still want to utilize the Object itself, we need to define a custom Outbound Implementation. This though does not work with 986, that is why I needed to copy 986 to Z_986:

Then we copy the Outbound Implementation 986 to the custom Outbound implementation Z_986_3

The logic behind the Outbound implementation is in a Class using the methods of interface IF_DRF_OUTBOUND. For 986_3 it is CL_MDG_BS_BP_REL_SERVICE_DRF

This class also needs to be copied into a Z-Class. For Z_986_3 I created Z_CL_DRF_2_AIFAEM_BP_REPL:

The class is referencing itself in the Constructor method. This needs to be changed to the new Z-Class. I have uploaded the Z-Class to my Github Repo here.

In IF_DRF_OUTBOUND~SEND_MESSAGE we have the Proxy Call

 

lo_bp_bupa_outbound->exec_async_out

 

Here in the parameter lt_bs_bp_data the Business Partner data is passed to the Proxy Method. Unfortunately not in the Format of the Outbound SOAP Interface, but Data Type mdg_bs_bp_t_extern .

With the "Where Used List" of this Data Type and Search (STRG + F) for "Map" I could find the Method CL_MDG_BP_BUPA_SI_OUT->DO_MAPPING_OUTBOUND. So I removed the Proxy Call and added the mapping and AIF Call

see Line 1158 in the Z-Class in the Github Repo mentioned above.

Now we are passing Data Type mdg_bp_bpsuitebulk_rplct_req_m to AIF. This is the Proxy Message type.

Of course our Outbound Implementation needs to be assigned to a Replication Model

This also needs to be activated on "Define Replication Model" Level.

 

2) AIF Customizing

For AIFAEM we need a Target Data Type with "CONTROLLER" and ""Since we are using a Proxy Data Type, we cannot design the Data Type in SE11, it has to be done either in SAP PO (ESR) and generated or in SPROXY. I decided to go with SPROXY.

  • SPXNGENAPPL -> Define Namespace for your Data Type
  • SPROXY -> Create -> Data Type. Here we need to reference the Data Type from the Standard Interface

Standard Proxy:

Custom Proxy:

In the Internal View we see the Name of the ABAP Structure we can use in AIF Interface Definition

Since Proxy Structures already use "CONTROLLER" Tables, we cannot name our AEM Controller Structure this way. This is why it is called CONTROLLER1.

Creation of  AIF Interface

Raw Structure = Structure passed from DRF to AIF

SAP Structure = Structure passed from AIF to AEM

AIF Structure Mapping:

Static topic. Can be adjusted to dynamic if needed.

Move-Corresponding, so we don´t have to map the individual Fields

Action:

Since we cannot use "CONTROLLER" which is needed in AIFAEM Standard Action, we need a Custom DRF Action, which is essentially a copy of the Standard Action, but with CONTROLLER1 referenced instead of CONTROLLER --> see Github Repo here 

 

Test

Let´s say i want to replicate this BusinessPartner:

 

Testing in DRFOUT:

--> manual Filter criteria

 

Success in the Logs:

 

/N/AIF/ERR

 

I consumed the topic in SAP Cloud Integration:

 

That´s it! Happy Eventing!

entry.title: Strengthening Financial Master Data with CDQ's Bank Account API: Real-Time Fraud Detection in MDG
entry.content:
Executive Summary 

Organizations face an increasing risk of fraud in vendor payments and financial master data. This blog introduces a lightweight SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) enhancement that integrates CDQ's Bank Account API to validate bank trustworthiness and detect fraud — in real-time — directly within the Change Request process. 

 

Introduction

Data quality in financial master data plays a crucial role in maintaining integrity and trust across the enterprise. Especially with increasing cases of fraud targeting bank account information, it has become vital to validate this data against trusted external sources. This blog post demonstrates how to integrate CDQ's Bank Account Data API into SAP MDG to detect and warn about known fraud cases in real time during the Change Request process. 

 

Background

Corporate Data Quality (CDQ) is a cloud-based platform that enables organizations to access verified, trusted data by connecting to official and commercial registers worldwide. While it is widely used for sourcing company information such as legal names, tax numbers, and registration data, CDQ also offers APIs for verifying bank accounts, which play a growing role in fraud prevention and financial data governance.

In my previous blog post, I demonstrated how to create a custom DPI integration solution in SAP for Business Partner creation using a Custom List UIBB and REST API calls to CDQ. This blog builds on that architectural pattern, extending it to the bank account domain using CDQ’s Bank Account Data API to validate and assess trust levels of banks directly within the Change Request process.

 

Feasible Option - Abstract

SAP MDG Classic Mode does not natively support dynamic bank account validation using external risk intelligence. However, this limitation can be overcome by integrating CDQ’s Bank Account Data API into the Change Request (CR) process via a custom-built API integration. This enables the following capabilities:

  • Fraud Detection: Detect if a bank is blacklisted or associated with a known fraud case.
  • Reputation Scoring: Retrieve and display the bank accounts' trust score for transparency and risk assessment.
  • Real-Time Messaging: Show contextual messages — either warnings (blacklisted) or information (whitelisted) — directly in the UI during CR processing.

For example:
If a blacklisted bank is entered: ⚠️ Bank & is in blacklist, one of fraud case ID: &

Figure 1 – Warning message after a bank in the blacklist is entered

 If a whitelisted bank is used with a known trust score: ✅ Bank & is in whitelist, trust score: &

Figure 2 – Information message after a bank in the whitelist is entered

This solution provides a feasible, low-effort, and value-driven way to bring real-time banking insights into your SAP MDG environment.

 

Some Nice-To-Have Skills

Here are some nice-to-have skills and knowledge areas for handling this topic:

ABAP programming, T-Code: SM59, SM30, STRUST, USMD_RULE_SERVICE BadI Definition, REST API, RFC, MDG

 

Solution in a Nutshell

This solution enhances SAP MDG's Change Request process by verifying bank account data in real time via CDQ’s Bank Account Data API. The goal is to detect potential fraud or confirm the trustworthiness of a bank at the moment it is entered in the Change Request.

Here's how it works:

  1. The user adds a bank account in a CR (only IBAN or bank account number & bank code/number & bank country code).
  2. Upon entry, background logic triggers a call to CDQ’s Bank Account Data API (POST /v2/bankaccounts/confirm).
  3. The response returns whether the bank:
    • ✅Is in the whitelist, along with a trust score (e.g., trustScore: 27).
    • ⚠️Has one or more fraud cases, with related metadata like fraudCaseId.
  4. SAP MDG then displays a contextual message in the UI based on the result:
    • If the bank is whitelisted: ✅ Bank 0002 is in whitelist, trust score: 27
    • If the bank is flagged for fraud: ⚠️ Bank 0001 is in blacklist, one of fraud case ID: UUIK5gGCQD

This provides immediate, actionable feedback to master data stewards before the data is activated, reducing the risk of onboarding risky bank accounts.

 

Implementation Steps

For our solution, we pursued the following steps:

  • Create an API Key Instance from CDQ with a Client ID and Client Secret. For more information, please visit this site.
  • Import TLS root certificate for https://api.cdq.com. For more information, check out this blog.
  • Maintain the required RFC Destinations to set up technical communication.
  • Determine the logical port as the DPI’s general RFC Destination. Configure the V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST view in SM30.
  • Create these classes to implement the logic;
    1. API Caller Class (ZCL_CDQ_API_CALLER) -> Handling API requests, communicating with CDQ
    2. Main Integration Class (ZCL_CDQ_BP_INTEGRATION) -> Prepare the request data and trigger the POST method
    3. Validation Class (ZCL_BP_CDQ_VALIDATION) -> Display the outcome of the API in Change Request
    4. Utilities Class (ZCL_BP_CDQ_UTILITIES) -> Collect useful methods that are used several times

Create New API Key;

Figure 3 – Generating API Key from CDQ Portal for Secure Integration

To establish secure HTTPS communication with CDQ, the certificate for api.cdq.com must be imported via transaction STRUST. This is depicted in Figure 4, where the certificate is added under the SSL Client (Standard);

Figure 4 – Certification for CDQ API

Set up External Server HTTP Connections;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Figure 5 – RFC Connections for CDQ

The created RFC Destination Z_DPI_CDQ is assigned as the logical port for DPI’s general operation. You can see this configuration in Figure 6, which shows the entry in the V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST view;

 

 

 

 


Figure 6 – Data entry for V_MDQDPI_RFCDEST to determine logical port for general DPI operations

Remark: The following methods will be the main part of the framework, they do not include the whole picture.
