The method responsible for communicating with CDQ (ZCL_CDQ_API_CALLER->CALL_API);

  METHOD call_api.

    TRY.
        DATA(rfc_destination) = get_rfc_destination( if_mdqdpi_rfc_dest_constants=>provider-cdq-operation-general-name ).

        IF rest_client IS NOT BOUND.
          DATA(http_client) = get_http_client( rfc_destination ).

          cl_http_utility=>set_request_uri( request = http_client->request
                                            uri     = api_path ).

          rest_client = NEW cl_rest_http_client( http_client ).
        ENDIF.

      CATCH cx_mdqdpi_functional_error.
        rfc_destination = get_rfc_destination( if_mdqdpi_rfc_dest_constants=>provider-cdq-operation-lookup-name ).
        IF rest_client IS NOT BOUND.
          http_client = get_http_client( rfc_destination ).
          rest_client = NEW cl_rest_http_client( http_client ).
        ENDIF.
        IF rest_client IS INITIAL.
          RAISE EXCEPTION NEW cx_mdqdpi_functional_error( textid = cx_mdqdpi_functional_error=>data_provider_setup_error ).
        ENDIF.
    ENDTRY.

    DATA(request) = build_request( payload = payload
                                   mapping = mapping ).
    rest_client->post( request ).
    result = rest_client->get_response_entity( )->get_string_data( ).
    analyze_response(
      EXPORTING
        string_response  = result
        rest_client      = rest_client                 " REST Client
      IMPORTING
        http_status_code = http_status_code
    ).

    rest_client->close( ).
    CLEAR rest_client.

  ENDMETHOD.

 The method responsible for preparing the API response for validation BAdI (ZCL_CDQ_BP_INTEGRATION->BANK_RELIABILITY);

  METHOD bank_reliability.

    DATA:
      ls_abap_format  TYPE zif_cdq_bp_integration=>gty_bank_reliability_response,
      ls_t100_message TYPE scx_t100key.

    CLEAR:
      ev_status,
      es_cdq_bank_response,
      et_t100_message.

    DATA(name_mappings) = VALUE /ui2/cl_json=>name_mappings( ( abap = 'bank_code'      json = 'nationalBankIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'iban'           json = 'internationalBankAccountIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'account_number' json = 'nationalBankAccountIdentifier' )
                                                             ( abap = 'bic'            json = 'internationalBankIdentifier' ) ).

    DATA(api_caller) = zcl_cdq_api_caller=>get_instance( ).

    TRY.
        api_caller->call_api(
          EXPORTING
            api_path         = '/sap-odm/v3/bankaccount-data/rest/v2/bankaccounts/confirm'
            payload          = is_cdq_bank_request
            mapping          = name_mappings                 " ABAP<->JSON Name Mapping Table
          IMPORTING
            result           = DATA(http_response)
            http_status_code = ev_status
        ).

      CATCH cx_mdqdpi_functional_error INTO DATA(lx_error).

*     General error message info
        CLEAR ls_t100_message.
        ls_t100_message = lx_error->if_t100_message~t100key.
        go_bp_cdq_utilities->prepare_t100_message(
          EXPORTING
            ix_error        = lx_error                 " Functional Errors
          CHANGING
            cs_t100_message = ls_t100_message                 " T100 key with mapping of parameters to attribute names
        ).
        IF ls_t100_message IS NOT INITIAL.
          APPEND ls_t100_message TO et_t100_message.
        ENDIF.

*     Detailed error message info if exists
        IF lx_error->previous IS NOT INITIAL.
          CLEAR ls_t100_message.
          DATA(lx_previos_error) = CAST cx_mdqdpi_functional_error( lx_error->previous ).
          ls_t100_message = lx_previos_error->if_t100_message~t100key.
          go_bp_cdq_utilities->prepare_t100_message(
            EXPORTING
              ix_error        = lx_previos_error                 " Functional Errors
            CHANGING
              cs_t100_message = ls_t100_message                 " T100 key with mapping of parameters to attribute names
          ).
          IF ls_t100_message IS NOT INITIAL.
            APPEND ls_t100_message TO et_t100_message.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.
        EXIT.
    ENDTRY.

    convert_to_abap_format(
      EXPORTING
        iv_data_in_json_format       = http_response
        iv_api_type                  = 'BANK_REL'                 " LOOK_UP / BANK_REL / EMAIL
      IMPORTING
        es_cdq_bank_response = es_cdq_bank_response                 " Bank Reliability Response Type
    ).

*  If the bank account has no trust score or fraud case, the bank account is unknown for CDQ
    IF      es_cdq_bank_response-trust_score            IS INITIAL
        AND es_cdq_bank_response-associated_fraud_cases IS INITIAL.
      es_cdq_bank_response-is_bank_unkown  = abap_true.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

 

Conclusion

As organizations increasingly rely on external banking data for payments, compliance, and onboarding, trusted bank account validation becomes a critical part of financial master data governance. This integration with CDQ’s Bank Account Data API provides SAP MDG users with real-time insights into the trust level and potential fraud risk of a bank—before the data is activated.

By embedding this verification into the Change Request process:

  • Stewards are empowered to act immediately on risks.
  • Fraud-prone banks can be flagged and avoided.
  • Clean, verified bank accounts improve downstream processes like payments and compliance reporting.

This approach not only enhances data quality and integrity but also supports key organizational goals: minimizing risk, preventing fraud, and building a solid foundation for digital finance processes.

Whether in finance, procurement, or vendor onboarding, this solution helps ensure that the bank accounts you rely on are exactly what they claim to be: trusted.

entry.title: Event enabling SAP Data Replication Framework with Advanced Event Mesh & RAP Business Events
entry.content:
Introduction

With todays enterprise landscapes becoming more and more distributed data movement and distribution is getting more and more relevant. In this blog I will go through the steps necessary to connect the SAP Data Replication Framework (DRF) with the SAP Integration Suite - Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) using RAP Business Events.

 

Disclaimer

The clean core approach for a connection between DRF and AEM, and I would recommend to apply this pattern, would be the Usage of a Standard DRF Replications provided by SAP which target an Iflow on Integration Suite (SOAP, XI or IDoc Sender Adapter) and pass the Event to AEM using the AEM Adapter. This would be a configuration only scenario and also can be monitored with SAP Application Interface Framework. 

The pattern explained in this blog is bypassing the BTP Cloud Integration and connecting to AEM directly. In addition especially for complex data structures a lot of development effort is required which makes it impractical for many use cases.

Prerequisites

This blog assumes that an AEM instance has already been setup and is connected to your S/4HANA system. Check out this blog for a detailed setup guide.

 

Setup

The setup of this pattern consists of two parts. The first one is the modelling of the event itself and the second one the required setup to trigger the event from the DRF. We'll be creating the event and everything required for it, as well as creating a custom DRF outbound implementation.

Creating the Event

Before we can send data as events to the AEM we need to develop the event itself. You can checkout this link for a details blog on how to create such events. To start lets create our BO to hold the event, starting with the initial data definition. For this blog I'll be replicating business partner data as such I'll be using the I_BusinessPartner view as root for my BO.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Business Partner BO for DRF 2 RAP Events'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP as select from I_BusinessPartner
{
    
    key BusinessPartner
}

 Next lets build the behaviour definition on top of it:

managed with unmanaged save implementation in class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;
}

Next we need to define the event payload itself. According to the exact requirements the payload needs to be modeled accordingly in the abstract entity. Check out this blog to see how to create more complex payloads with deep structures. In this example I'll be creating just a very simple payload with the first and last name. The business partner number will automatically be included in the event as the key field of the BO.

@EndUserText.label: 'Payload for BP DRF'
define abstract entity Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP_PAYLOAD
{
    FirstName : abap.char(40);
    LastName : abap.char(40);
    
}

Next lets define the event itself on the behaviour definition. Reference the abstract entity and don't forget the deep keyword if you are using a nested payload structure.

managed with unmanaged save implementation in class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;

  event DRF_REPLICATION parameter Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP_PAYLOAD;
}

 Next we can define the implementation class for our BO. As events can only be triggered within the implementation class of a BO we need to create and expose a wrapper method that we later can call from the DRF. For this lets define a class-method within our global class. This method should import the business partner number so that we can raise the specific event.

CLASS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp DEFINITION PUBLIC ABSTRACT FINAL FOR BEHAVIOR OF z_drf_2_rap_bp.

    PUBLIC SECTION.
        CLASS-METHODS raise_drf_event
            IMPORTING iv_bp TYPE BU_PARTNER.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp IMPLEMENTATION.

    METHOD raise_drf_event.
        lcl_event_handler=>on_Raise_DRF_Event( iv_bp ).
    ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

We can then raise the event within the local types. I've added a select to collect all of the required data for the business partner and pass it to the event.

CLASS lcl_event_handler DEFINITION FRIENDS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS on_Raise_DRF_Event IMPORTING iv_bp TYPE BU_PARTNER.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_handler IMPLEMENTATION.
   METHOD on_Raise_DRF_Event.

    DATA: tt_events TYPE TABLE FOR EVENT z_drf_2_rap_bp~drf_replication.

    SELECT SINGLE
        BusinessPartner, FirstName, LastName
        FROM I_BusinessPartner
        WHERE BusinessPartner = @( |{ iv_bp ALPHA = IN }| )
        INTO (s_bupa).

    tt_events = VALUE #(
        (
            businesspartner = s_bupa-BusinessPartner
            firstName = s_bupa-FirstName
            lastName = s_bupa-LastName
        )
    ).

    RAISE ENTITY EVENT z_drf_2_rap_bp~drf_replication FROM tt_events.

   ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

Next lets create the event binding to assign the event a topic:

 

After everything is activated you can call this method from any context to trigger the event.

 

DRF Customising

The customising of the DRF is nearly identical to the one described in Alex blog about connecting DRF with AIFAEM.

The standard object we are trying to use is 986 - Business Partner. You'll find it in DRFIMG -> Enhance Default Settings for Outbound Implementations -> Define Business Objects. The corresponding Outbound Implementation (using the standard SOAP Proxy) is 986_3. For our use case we need a custom Outbound Implementation based on this object. As such we need to copy the object to a new custom one. I named mine Z_986_3_RP

To be able to connect our RAP business event with DRF we need to adjust the outbound implementation class. Therefore we need to copy the standard implementation class of 986_3 (CL_MDG_BS_BP_REL_SERVICE_DRF) to a new custom class and reference it in our Outbound Implementation class Z_986_3_RP. I named mine Z_CL_DRF_2_RAP_BP_REPL

The class is referencing itself at multiple points. This needs to be adjusted to the new Z-Class. In addition some further mappings have to be performed which Alex described in his blog. The complete coding for the implementation of this blog can be found in the attached txt file.

The most important adjustment is however the call to our previously defined wrapper method raise_drf_event in our implementation class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp. For this I added a loop over the different entries which calls this method and passes the business partner number.

LOOP AT ls_rap_raw-business_partner_suitereplicat INTO DATA(ls_entry).

                DATA(ev_bp) = ls_entry-business_partner-internal_id.

                TRY.
                    CALL METHOD zbp_drf_2_rap_bp=>raise_drf_event
                     EXPORTING
                      iv_bp = ev_bp.

                CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_root).
                 MESSAGE lx_root->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
                ENDTRY.
            ENDLOOP.

Depending on the required payload of the event this can be further improved by removing the select from the method implementation and passing the data directly from the original structure.

This new Outbound Implementation needs to be assigned to a replication model.

 

This also needs to be activated within "Define Replication Model" level.

 

Test

To test this setup lets replicate the following business partner:

Create the event binding by opening transaction /IWXBE/OUTBOUND_CFG, selecting your broker and creating a new topic binding for your respective topic

 

Open transaction DRFOUT and select your replication model

Also set the manual filter criteria:

 

Press execute. The logs should then display a success.

The event itself can then be viewed in the Event Monitor (transaction /IWXBE/EVENT_MONITOR)

entry.title: SAP MDG-M Custom UI Configuration Performance Comparison and Gains
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP MDG-M, the standard User Interface (UI) is designed to load the full set of content, ensuring complete visibility but often at the cost of speed and responsiveness. While this “load-everything” approach guarantees access to all data, it also introduces performance bottlenecks that slow down day-to-day work. 

As a team, we explored ways to mitigate these performance challenges and developed a Custom UI solution tailored to our specific needs. But how much of a difference does this new UI make?

To answer this, we conducted structured performance tests, analyzing key factors such as page load times, system resource utilization, and user feedback. This study will reveal the concrete benefits of the new Custom UI compared to standard UIs, providing insights for future optimization efforts.

Background

A good user experience is a key requirement for any user-centric application. As SAP MDG is an enterprise solution involving hundreds of fields per domain, it’s very important to display the relevant role-specific information at each governance process step in a user-friendly manner. This will help the data stewards and data analysts make smart decisions with the help of simple and responsive UIs. 

Standard UIs provide a solid foundation for these processes, ensuring consistency and reliability across the system. As data volumes and usage scenarios expand, however, opportunities emerge to further optimize performance.

User feedback and technical performance analyses highlighted areas where the standard UIs could be further optimized — particularly around load times, resource usage, and navigation flow. To address these opportunities, our team designed a Custom UI solution focused on boosting performance and enhancing usability, while still building on the strengths of the existing framework. 

In this study, we assess the impact of Custom UIs on performance and compare them with existing standard UIs. The goal is to determine the areas where improvements have been achieved.

Test Methodology and Scope

To measure these differences objectively, we conducted rigorous performance tests under identical conditions.

For performance analysis, we focused on the following criteria:
  • Page Load Time: A crucial factor affecting user experience
  • System Resource Utilization: Efficiency in memory (RAM), CPU, and database queries
  • User Feedback: Objective evaluation through surveys and scores

Tests were conducted under predefined conditions using identical datasets. Below are the tools and test conditions used.

Testing Tool:  Http Trace Using

UI Type: Standard UI (BS_MAT_OVP_09H) - Average Load Time: 1789 msn


Figure 1 – Standard UI http trace

UI Type: Custom UI (Z9H_BS_MAT_OVP_09H) - Average Load Time: 858 msn


Figure 2 – Custom UI http trace

System Resource Utilization (Memory, CPU, Database Queries)

UI Type: Standart UI - AT_OVP~BS_MAT_OVP_09


Figure 3 – Standard UI System Resource Utilization

UI Type: Custom UI - P~Z9H_BS_MAT_OVP_09H


Figure 4 – Custom UI System Resource Utilization

The performance metrics above may vary depending on several factors such as the density of data in the database, system resource usage, network speed, and similar elements. Therefore, performance results may differ under varying conditions.

Results and Gains

Our analysis revealed clear benefits that directly strengthen both system efficiency and the user experience. The enhancements not only streamline resource usage but also make the UI more responsive and enjoyable to work with — especially in large-scale data operations

Here’s a summary of the key gains achieved with the Custom UI:
  • Performance Improvement: Noticeably faster page load times, ensuring smoother workflows.
  • Optimized Resource Utilization: Reduced memory and CPU usage, allowing the system to run more efficiently.
  • Higher User Satisfaction: Improved usability and more positive user feedback, reflecting greater engagement.

Thank you for reading,

Best regards.

Ahmet

entry.title: Artificial Intelligence and SAP Master Data Governance
entry.content:
It is a no brainer that high-speed availability of elevated quality data is crucial in state-of-the-art master data processing. Therefore, SAP Master Data Governance addresses this topic for quite a while with features like: 

  • ML-based rule mining  
  • derivation of field values  
  • data provider integration for the automated take-over of proven reference data from 3rd party data providers and 
  • most recently with the integration of generative AI 

AI is a game changer in many fields, and therefore I’d like to shed light on its ever increasing impact on master data processing.

The Impact of AI on Master Data Governance: A New Era of Intelligent Data Management

In today’s digital economy, data is more than just an asset - it’s the foundation of business intelligence, compliance, and operational success. Among the many types of enterprise data, master data - including customer, vendor, and product data - plays a central role in ensuring consistency and accuracy across systems. However, managing and governing this data has traditionally been a complex, manual, and error-prone process.

With the rise of Artificial Intelligence (AI), master data governance is undergoing an additional transformation. AI brings speed, intelligence, and automation to data governance processes, enabling organizations to maintain high data quality standards while significantly reducing manual effort and cost. AI benefits are in the hands of Master Data Management business users as they will be empowered using functions in SAP Master Data Governance, without additional tools and training and with increased flexibility and ease governing business partner data in future.

Challenges of Ungoverned Master Data

Organizations that rely on ungoverned master data practices face numerous challenges:

  • Manual data entry is prone to human error and inconsistencies across departments and systems.
  • Duplicate or outdated records compromise decision-making and customer experience.
  • Global data compliance requirements make it harder to enforce consistent rules and formats.

These challenges can lead to poor data quality, inefficiencies, and even financial and reputational risks.

AI’s Transformational Role in Master Data Management

AI has the potential to enhance every aspect of master data governance. From automating routine tasks to predicting and preventing errors, AI can enable organizations to transition from reactive data management to proactive data stewardship. This includes the following aspects:

Data Quality and Cleansing

AI algorithms could automatically identify missing, incomplete, or inconsistent data. For example, if a product entry lacks a critical attribute, AI can detect the issue and either correct it or flag it for review. Natural Language Processing (NLP) helps interpret unstructured data, enabling organizations to extract and standardize information from disparate sources.

Intelligent Matching and Deduplication

AI excels at fuzzy matching, which is critical for identifying duplicate records that may not be exact matches. Whether it's variations in customer names, addresses, or product codes, AI learns from historical corrections to improve deduplication over time, even across different languages or local conventions.

Predictive Data Governance

AI could proactively monitor data entry patterns and detect anomalies before they create downstream problems. For instance, if a vendor record deviates from standard formats or contains unusual combinations of data, AI can suggest corrections or flag it for review.

Workflow Automation and Smart Approvals

AI could optimize approval workflows by learning from past decisions and routing requests to the right people automatically. This reduces the cycle time for master data changes and ensures compliance with governance policies without unnecessary delays.

Data Steward Assistance

Data stewards benefit from AI acting as a co-pilot - suggesting actions, prioritizing issues, and providing insights. AI-powered chatbots or virtual assistants can help them query records, update data, or perform validations faster and more accurately.

Current scope and trends in SAP Master Data Governance

 SAP MDG has started embedding AI and machine learning into its framework to enhance data quality and governance automation. Please read following recent articles for a clearer picture: 

  • Inclusion of Generative AI in MDG (as of SAP S/4HANA 2023 Cloud Private Edition Feature Pack Stack 02) 
    used for summary of changes and assisted changes in central governance (classic mode), and for optional business partner processing (in cloud-ready mode) initiated by a Joule dialog. 
  • Gen AI-based assisted change for custom objects and summary of mass changes (as of SAP S/4HANA 2023 Cloud Private Edition Feature Pack Stack 03) 
    AI-assisted changes in central governance for reuse entities in custom objects and AI-based summary of change requests with multiple objects (mass changes). 
  • Master Data Governance Facilitating Generative AI 
    Blog post on how generative AI impacts master data management and vice versa. 

The AI-enabled SAP Joule assistant utilizes natural language processing to allow employees to execute professional Master Data Governance tasks, such as updating business partner information and checking governance workflows, without needing deep MDG expertise. To get the full picture of planned AI innovations in SAP Master Data Governance across the entire MDG solution portfolio, see the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

And finally, I would also like to refer to the following planned AI Webinar: Upcoming MDM Webinar (October 15th) with the Hackett Group

This webinar is with The Hackett Group and focused on the recent Hackett Group World Class Matrix for MDM Software, in which SAP participated. It is a live, interactive webinar, that will journey through the evolution of Master Data Management (MDM) – from its foundational role in process improvement to its impact on analytical and AI outcomes. We will wrap up with a summary of the capabilities of SAP Master Data Governance for operational excellence and accurate analytics and AI as well as discuss how AI within MDM is driving new value.

The registration page is available here: https://event.on24.com/wcc/r/5071369/89EF715DACF727EA399DE330113B0340. 

The impact is measurable: reduced manual effort, fewer data errors, and improved compliance.

Additional Considerations going forward

AI holds great promise for the future, following considerations shall always be kept in mind:

  • Data bias: AI models will have to be trained on diverse and accurate datasets to avoid reinforcing existing biases. MDG can provide proper basis for this.
  • Data privacy: Organizations must ensure that AI respects privacy laws like GDPR and CCPA when processing sensitive master data.
  • Model transparency: AI decisions, such as why a record was flagged or approved, must be explainable and auditable.
  • Human oversight: AI should augment - not replace - human governance. Final decisions should remain with accountable physical persons.

The benefit lies in the strong hand in hand co-work of proven master data governance augmented by AI innovation aspects.

Conclusion

AI has the potential to revolutionize master data governance by making it smarter, faster, and more proactive. By automating manual processes, improving data quality, and enhancing governance workflows. AI empowers organizations to manage their most critical data assets with greater agility and confidence with one stop-shop - Joule.

As businesses strive for digital transformation, adopting AI in MDG is not just a technological upgrade - it’s a strategic imperative. The organizations that embrace this shift now will be the ones that lead in data-driven innovation tomorrow.

As AI technologies mature, organizations will move from data maintenance to intelligent data orchestration - turning governance into a strategic advantage.

I hope this information sharing about Joule insights within MDG is interesting for you to read. If you enjoyed this article, be sure to subscribe and leave us a review. Until next time, keep innovating and stay curious! 

To stay on track, simply follow the SAP Community Topic Page for SAP Master Data Governance, read the MDG-related blogs, and join the  Q&A forum. 

Best, 
Ria

entry.title: SAP MDG: Based on Grouping, Tax Number is Mandatory
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note: This blog does not include execution screenshots.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to make the Tax Number field mandatory for specific Groupings. The logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via BADI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY.

Prerequisite: A working knowledge of BADI USMD_RULE_SERVICE and ABAP development is required to follow this implementation.

Development Details

  • Target Groupings: ZSGP, ZSGC
  • Message Class: ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS
  • Message Number: 001
  • Message Type: E
  • Message Text: Tax Number is Mandatory !!!
  • BADI Method Implemented: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY 

    The validation logic is written directly in the method CHECK_ENTITY

    This ensures that when the specified groupings are selected, the system enforces the presence of a Tax Number and raises a custom message if it's missing.

Code:

 

  METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.
    CALL METHOD io_model->read_entity_data_all
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname    = 'BP_HEADER'            
        if_active      = abap_false            
        i_crequest     = id_crequest            " Change Request
      IMPORTING
        et_data_entity = DATA(lt_data).        " Data for Entity Types
    .
    READ TABLE lt_data INTO DATA(ls_data) WITH KEY usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = ' ' struct = 'KATTR'.
    ASSIGN ls_data-r_t_data->* TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lt_data>).
    LOOP AT <lt_data> ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_data>).
      ASSIGN COMPONENT 'BU_GROUP' OF STRUCTURE <ls_data> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_group>).
      IF <lv_group> IS ASSIGNED AND
         <lv_group> EQ 'ZSGP' OR
         <lv_group> EQ 'ZSGC'.
        READ TABLE lt_data INTO ls_data WITH KEY usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_TAXNUM' struct = 'KATTR'.
        IF sy-subrc <> 0.
          et_message = VALUE #( ( msgid = 'ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS' msgty = 'E' msgno = '001' ) ).
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.


SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: SAP MDG: Validation - No Special Characters in Account Holder Field
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to restrict the use of special characters in the Account Holder field. The validation logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via BADI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY. This ensures data consistency and compliance with formatting standards during master data creation and change processes.

Prerequisite: A working knowledge of BADI USMD_RULE_SERVICE and ABAP development is required to follow this implementation.

Development Details

  • Message Class: ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS
  • Message Number: 002
  • Message Type: E
  • Message Text: The Account Holder field must not contain any special characters
  • BADI Method Implemented: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY 

    The validation logic is written directly in the method CHECK_ENTITY

    This ensures that when the Account Holder field is entered, the system validates the content to ensure it does not contain any special characters, and raises a custom message if invalid characters are found

Code:

 METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.
   DATA: lt_data        TYPE usmd_ts_data_entity,
         lt_bank_data   TYPE REF TO data,
         lt_msg         TYPE usmd_t_message,
         ls_msg         TYPE usmd_s_message,
         lv_fieldname   TYPE bu_koinh,
         lv_acc_holder TYPE char20.
   FIELD-SYMBOLS:
     <lt_bank>        TYPE SORTED TABLE,
     <ls_bank>        TYPE any,
     <lv_acc_holder> TYPE any.
   io_model->get_changed_fields(
     IMPORTING	
       et_entity_fieldname =  DATA(lt_fieldname)               
   )
   .
   LOOP AT lt_fieldname INTO DATA(ls_fieldname).
     lv_fieldname = ls_fieldname-fieldname.
     IF lv_fieldname = 'KOINH'.
       lv_acc_holder = lv_fieldname.
     ENDIF.
   ENDLOOP.
   IF lv_acc_holder = 'KOINH'.
     io_model->read_entity_data_all(
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname      =       'BP_HEADER'           " Financial MDM: Field Name
        if_active        =         abap_false          " Financial MDM: General Indicator
    i_crequest       =            id_crequest          " Change Request
      IMPORTING
    et_message       =        lt_msg          " Messages
        et_data_entity   =      lt_data            " Data for Entity Types
    ).
     lt_bank_data = VALUE #( lt_data[ usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_BKDTL' struct = 'KATTR' ]-r_t_data  OPTIONAL ).
     IF lt_bank_data IS NOT INITIAL.
       ASSIGN lt_bank_data->* TO <lt_bank>.
       IF <lt_bank> IS ASSIGNED.
         LOOP AT <lt_bank> ASSIGNING <ls_bank>.
           ASSIGN COMPONENT 'KOINH' OF STRUCTURE <ls_bank> TO <lv_acc_holder>.
           IF <lv_acc_holder> IS ASSIGNED AND
              <lv_acc_holder> IS NOT INITIAL AND                        
             <lv_acc_holder> CA '~`!@#$%^&*()-_+={}[]|\:;"<,>.?/'.
             et_message = VALUE #( BASE et_message ( fieldname = 'KOINH' msgid = 'ZMDGS_MESSAGE_CLS' msgno = '002' msgty = 'E' ) ).
           ENDIF.
         ENDLOOP.
       ENDIF.
     ENDIF.
   ENDIF.
 ENDMETHOD.

entry.title: SAP MDG: Validation - Notes Mandatory
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to enforce mandatory entry of Notes during master data processes. The validation logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via:
BADI:USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY.

This ensures that users provide the required notes, thereby improving data completeness, auditability, and compliance during master data creation and change activities.

Code:

DATA:
  lv_cr_number TYPE usmd_crequest,
  lv_crtype    TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
  lv_process   TYPE usmd_process.

DATA(lo_context) = cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context( ).

IF lo_context IS BOUND.
  CALL METHOD lo_context->get_attributes
    IMPORTING
      ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
      ev_crequest_type = lv_crtype
      ev_process       = lv_process.
ENDIF.

IF lv_crtype EQ 'ZSUCRTYPE'.
  DATA(lv_s_notes) = cl_usmd_conv_som_gov_api=>get_instance( )->get_notes( ).
       IF lv_s_notes IS INITIAL.
          APPEND cl_usmd_message=>convert_text2message(
          EXPORTING
          iv_message_text = 'Please Maintain Notes, It''s Mandatory !!!'.
          iv_message_type = 'E' ) to et_message.
       ENDIF.
ENDIF.

 

SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: SAP MDG : Accessing Change Request Data by Business Activity & Change Request Type
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.
Note 03: There are several ways; this blog is written about one of them.

Create one custom class, with 02 methods:

ZCL_MDGS_ASSISTIVE

GET_INSTANCE_GOV_API

* <SIGNATURE>---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
* | Static Public Method ZCL_MDGS_ASSISTIVE=>GET_INSTANCE_GOV_API
* +-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
* | [--->] IV_MODEL                       TYPE        USMD_MODEL
* | [<---] EV_INSTANCE_EXISTS             TYPE        ABAP_BOOL
* | [<---] EO_GOV_API                     TYPE REF TO CL_USMD_GOV_API
* +--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</SIGNATURE>
  METHOD get_instance_gov_api.
    DATA: lo_gov_api   TYPE REF TO if_usmd_gov_api,
          lo_cx_root   TYPE REF TO cx_root,
          lv_exception TYPE        string.
    IF cl_usmd_gov_api=>check_instance_exists( iv_model_name = iv_model ) EQ abap_false.
      ev_instance_exists = abap_false.
      TRY.
          cl_usmd_gov_api=>get_instance(
            EXPORTING
              iv_model_name = iv_model
            RECEIVING
              ro_gov_api    = lo_gov_api
          ).
        CATCH cx_usmd_gov_api INTO lo_cx_root.
          lv_exception = lo_cx_root->get_text( ).
      ENDTRY.
      IF lv_exception IS INITIAL AND
         lo_gov_api   IS BOUND.
        eo_gov_api ?= lo_gov_api.
      ENDIF.
    ELSE.
      ev_instance_exists = abap_true.
      TRY.
          cl_usmd_gov_api=>get_instance(
            EXPORTING
              iv_model_name = iv_model
            RECEIVING
              ro_gov_api    = lo_gov_api
          ).
        CATCH cx_usmd_gov_api INTO lo_cx_root.
          lv_exception = lo_cx_root->get_text( ).
      ENDTRY.
      IF lv_exception IS INITIAL AND
         lo_gov_api   IS BOUND.
        eo_gov_api ?= lo_gov_api.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

GET_CR_DATA 
(***Note: above method making use in this method)

* <SIGNATURE>---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
* | Static Public Method ZCL_MDGS_ASSISTIVE=>GET_CR_DATA
* +-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
* | [--->] IV_CR_ID                       TYPE        USMD_CREQUEST
* | [<-->] CS_CR_ATTRIBUTES               TYPE        USMD_S_CREQUEST(optional)
* | [<-->] CV_MODEL                       TYPE        USMD_MODEL(optional)
* | [<-->] CV_CR_TYPE_PROCESS             TYPE        USMD_PROCESS(optional)
* | [<-()] RT_CR_DATA                     TYPE        USMD_TS_ENTITY_DATA_ALL
* +--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</SIGNATURE>
    METHOD get_cr_data.
    DATA: lo_gov_api     TYPE REF TO  cl_usmd_gov_api,
          lt_cr_data     TYPE         usmd_ts_entity_data_all,
          lv_model       TYPE         usmd_model,
          lv_inst_exists TYPE         abap_bool.
    " Determine the  model from CR ID to get the instance of
    " Goverance API.
    CHECK IV_CR_ID IS NOT INITIAL.
    IF NOT cv_model IS INITIAL.
      lv_model = cv_model.
    ELSE.
      cl_usmd_crequest_util=>get_model_by_cr(
        EXPORTING
          i_crequest = iv_cr_id
        IMPORTING
          e_model    = cv_model
      ).
    ENDIF.
    " Get the instance of the governance API
    IF NOT cv_model IS INITIAL.
      ZCL_MDGS_ASSISTIVE=>get_instance_gov_api(
        EXPORTING
          iv_model           = cv_model
        IMPORTING
          ev_instance_exists = lv_inst_exists
          eo_gov_api         = lo_gov_api
      ).
      " Read the data of the CR data using the Governance API
      IF lo_gov_api IS BOUND.
        lo_gov_api->if_usmd_gov_api_cr_data~get_crequest_data(
          EXPORTING
            iv_crequest_id          = iv_cr_id
          IMPORTING
            et_entity_data_inactive = rt_cr_data
        ).
        " CR Header Data
        cs_cr_attributes = lo_gov_api->if_usmd_gov_api_cr_data~get_crequest_attributes( iv_crequest_id = iv_cr_id  ).
        " CR Business activity or Business Process ID
        SELECT SINGLE usmd_process
                 FROM usmd1601
                 INTO _cr_type_process
                WHERE usmd_creq_type = _cr_attributes-usmd_creq_type.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

Now, Making use of ZCL_MDGS_ASSISTIVE in system method caller implementation (if_usmd_ssw_syst_method_caller~call_system_method)

DATA: 
ls_crequest     TYPE usmd_s_crequest,
lv_model        TYPE usmd_model,
lv_cr_process   TYPE usmd_process,
lt_cr_data      TYPE usmd_ts_entity_data_all,
lt_supp_data  TYPE REF TO data.

FIELD-SYMBOLS:
<lt_supp_data> TYPE SORTED TABLE,
<ls_supp_data> TYPE any,
<lv_fno> TYPE any.

CALL METHOD zcl_mdgs_assistive=>get_cr_data
      EXPORTING
        iv_cr_id           = iv_cr_number
      CHANGING
        cs_cr_attributes   = ls_crequest
        cv_model           = lv_model
        cv_cr_type_process = lv_cr_process
      RECEIVING
        rt_cr_data         = lt_cr_data.

IF ls_crequest-usmd_creq_type = 'ZMDGS01',
 IF lv_cr_process = 'SUP1'.
  lt_supp_data = VALUE #( lt_cr_data[ usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_CENTRL' struct = 'KATTR' ]-r_data  OPTIONAL ). 
   IF lt_supp_data IS BOUND .
    ASSIGN lt_supp_data->* TO <lt_supp_data>.
     IF <lt_supp_data> IS ASSIGNED.
      LOOP AT <lt_supp_data> ASSIGNING <ls_supp_data>.
       ASSIGN COMPONENT 'NAME_ORG1' OF STRUCTURE <ls_supp_data> TO <lv_fno>.
        IF <lv_fno> IS ASSIGNED AND <lv_fno> IS NOT INITIAL.
         .
         . "Requirement Logic etc...
         .
        ENDIF.
       ENDLOOP.
     ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
   ENDIF.
ENDIF.

SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Innovations in Master Data Governance with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025
entry.content:
Continuing the blog series about innovations in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG), I'd like to share information about the key innovations in master data governance coming with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025.

Key Innovations include:

  • Continuous improvements in central governance (classic mode)​
  • Use of generative AI for governance processes (applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition only, innovations in classic mode and in cloud-ready mode)​
  • Improvements in data quality management (classic mode and cloud-ready mode)
  • Revamped data provider integration for the provisioning of business-partner reference data​ (cloud-ready mode)
  • Application-agnostic legal hierarchies (business partner, cloud-ready mode)​

Key Innovations in Detail

Let me explain the innovations in more detail, according to the categories listed above. 

Continuous improvements in central governance (classic mode)​

This covers improvements in central governance of material, business partner, and financial data.

  • Material data:
    • Support for commodity codes comes integrated into the MDG UI as a separate User Interface Building Block (UIBB). Commodity codes from different numbering schemes can be assigned to a material and different valid from and to intervals can be maintained.
    • Input value help for characteristic (F4) now with assigned check table enables search either using the first 15 fields of the check table or Data Dictionary (DDIC) search help if it is assigned to the check table.
  • Financial data:
    • Inclusion of joint venture accounting fields as attributes of cost centers, profit centers, G/L accounts, and internal orders incl. validation checks and replication. 

      Use of joint venture accounting (JVA) fields as attributes of profit center
  • Propagation of changes done in an edition to the future edition to eliminate the need for repetitive updates across editions.

    Propagation of edition
  • Additionally, HANA-based search can be used as default search option.
  • Business partner data:
    • Enhanced client maintenance (de-central governance) scenarios depending on conditions such as create versus change scenarios, the actual client system sending the data, or the data to be processed.
    • Assignment of one or more data controllers and associated purpose to a business partner.
    • Enhanced IBAN converter (specifically for countries that require both an IBAN and a bank key) and alternative IBAN display format.
    • Document assignments on business partner level (create, change, or delete document assignments for business partners whether customer, supplier, or both in new Documents UIBB).
    • ​​Display of the validity of sales areas and purchasing organizations in the input help.
    • Entry of maintain payment reasons for customers or suppliers for general or company code data and maintenance of recipient types for Customer Extended Withholding Tax data.

Maintenance of payment reasons for customers or suppliers and maintenance of recipient type for customer extended withholding tax data

Use of generative AI for governance processes

On the one hand, this covers the use of embedded AI for additional entities in assisted changes and summary of changes in central governance (when using classic mode). In particular, the inclusion of flex entities in generative AI-assisted changes in the central governance of business partner, material, and custom objects, and the inclusion edition-based entities in AI-generated summary of changes in the central governance of business partner, finance, material and custom objects.​

On the other​, it is about the use of Joule copilot to govern business partner data and run spot-checks on MDG process status (when using cloud-ready mode):

  • ​Natural-language based prompts in Joule can be used to search, display, create, and change business partner data. 

Using Joule copilot for changing business partner data

  • Based on planned Joule content delivery, it is also planned to enable the search and display of specific information related to master data governance processes from November 2025 on.

Using Joule to search and display information about MDG processes

Improvements in data quality management (classic mode and cloud-ready mode)

There are various new features in the validation rules app for business partners and products. This includes capabilities to:

  • Copy validation rules
  • Create validation rules that check if a master data governance process has an attachment
  • Delete the validation rules' dependencies to other objects (for example, simulations, dimensions, or data quality evaluation runs) when deleting rules
  • Disable several validation rules at once
  • Filter for enabled usages, disabled usages and usages in general

Filtering validation rules for enabled usages

Revamped data provider integration for the provisioning of business-partner reference data​ (cloud-ready mode)

This enables integration with an external data provider of your choice for automated use of high-quality data in governance processes using SAP Cloud Integration​.  With SAP Cloud Integration, you can connect any data provider to the business-partner domain, leveraging high-quality compliant reference data for searching and creating business partners.

Data provider integration

  1. Enter search term to check if the required business partner is already there.

  2. As this is not the case, click "Go" to connect with data provider reference data.

  3. Select the appropriate entry and create business partner with auto-populated fields.

Individually created SAP Cloud Integration packages provide you with the capability to connect with the data provider API and map between the data provider data model and the SAP data model of business partner. 

With a pre-defined SAP Cloud Integration package, accessible from SAP Business Hub, you can integrate your SAP Master Data Governance application efficiently and with less effort with the data provider Corporate Data Quality (CDQ). This plug-and-play package ensures default mapping from the data provider specific data model to the SAP business partner data model.

Application-agnostic legal hierarchies (business partner, cloud-ready mode)​

This new app provides governance of an aligned, application-agnostic legal business partner hierarchy representing the company ownership.  With this app you can:

  • Create, display, and delete business partner hierarchies​​
  • Create, edit, and delete nodes​​
  • Search for existing business partner hierarchies and nodes​​
  • Assign a business partner to a node

This way you can achieve a single source of truth for legal ownership data across all applications and support for compliance with regulatory and audit requirements while being able to make faster decisions based on the easy creation and updates of ownership structures.

More information

See also the presentation outlining the MDG delta content coming with SAP S/4HANA 2025 Cloud Private Edition .

To get the full picture of planned innovations in SAP Master Data Governance across the entire MDG solution portfolio, see the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

To stay up to date, simply follow the SAP Community Topic Page for SAP Master Data Governance and join the Q&A and discussion forum.

entry.title: SAP MDG: How to Grey Out Copy Button in ERP Vendor: Purchasing Organizations UIBB ?
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.
Note 03: There are several ways; this blog is written about one of them.

Create customizing or enhance UIBB.

Standard Feeder Class: CL_BS_SP_GUIBB_PURCH_ORGS.

Create one custom class: ZCL_MDGS_GUIBB_PURCH_ORGS & do inherit above standard feeder class.

Now, utilize this method:  METHOD if_fpm_guibb_list~get_data.

Code:

CALL METHOD super->if_fpm_guibb_list~get_data
      EXPORTING
        iv_eventid                = iv_eventid
        it_selected_fields        = it_selected_fields
        iv_raised_by_own_ui       = iv_raised_by_own_ui
        iv_visible_rows           = iv_visible_rows
        iv_edit_mode              = iv_edit_mode
        io_extended_ctrl          = io_extended_ctrl
      IMPORTING
        et_messages               = et_messages
        ev_data_changed           = ev_data_changed
        ev_field_usage_changed    = ev_field_usage_changed
        ev_action_usage_changed   = ev_action_usage_changed
        ev_selected_lines_changed = ev_selected_lines_changed
        ev_dnd_attr_changed       = ev_dnd_attr_changed
        eo_itab_change_log        = eo_itab_change_log
      CHANGING
        ct_data                   = ct_data
        ct_field_usage            = ct_field_usage
        ct_action_usage           = ct_action_usage
        ct_selected_lines         = ct_selected_lines
        cv_lead_index             = cv_lead_index
        cv_first_visible_row      = cv_first_visible_row
        cs_additional_info        = cs_additional_info
        ct_dnd_attributes         = ct_dnd_attributes.

DATA :
      lv_cr_number TYPE usmd_crequest,
      lv_crtype    TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
      lv_process   TYPE usmd_process.

DATA(lo_context) = cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context( ).

IF lo_context IS BOUND.
   CALL METHOD lo_context->get_attributes
        IMPORTING
          ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
          ev_crequest_type = lv_crtype
          ev_process       = lv_process.
ENDIF.

IF lv_crtype EQ 'ZMDGS01'.
  READ TABLE ct_action_usage ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_copy>) WITH KEY id = 'BOL_COPY'.
   <lfs_copy>-visible = '01'.
ENDIF.

 

SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.

entry.title: From Foundation to Future: Master Data Management as the Fuel for Gen AI
entry.content:
In today's fast-paced business landscape, the role of Master Data Management (MDM) has evolved significantly, transitioning from a fundamental process improvement tool to a critical enabler of advanced analytics and AI. Join us for an interactive webinar, "From Foundation to Future: Master Data Management as the Fuel for Gen AI," where we delve into the evolution of MDM and its pivotal role in empowering next-generation AI technologies.

What to Expect

Introduction to The Hackett Group and Their Latest MDM Study

Kickstarting our session, we will introduce The Hackett Group and share insights from their latest 2025 MDM study. This will set the tone for our detailed discussion on the evolution and impact of Master Data Management.

Traditional Applications of MDM

We will then explore the traditional applications of MDM, highlighting its role in business process improvement. Through line-of-business-specific examples, you'll gain a clear understanding of how MDM has been utilized to streamline operations and enhance efficiency.

Contemporary MDM Use Cases

Diving deeper, we will examine more contemporary MDM use cases to illustrate how clean master data drives effective analytics, AI, and ultimately, improved decision-making. These examples will underscore the transformative potential of MDM in today's data-driven world.

SAP Master Data Governance

We will weave in throughout the capabilities of SAP Master Data Governance, demonstrating its role in achieving operational excellence and accurate analytics. Moreover, we will discuss how AI within MDM is driving new value and accelerating business process excellence.

Meet Our Speakers

Bryan DeGraw, Market Intelligence Analyst

Bryan DeGraw, Market Intelligence Analyst at The Hackett Group, is the author of their MDM Matrix Study. His insights and expertise in MDM will provide a comprehensive understanding of its past, present, and future.

Andreas Seifried, SAP MDM Product Management

Andreas Seifried, from SAP MDM Product Management, will share his knowledge on how SAP Master Data Governance can fuel enable businesses to stay ahead in the competitive marketplace.

Why Attend?

1. Insightful Perspectives: Gain valuable insights from industry experts on the evolution of MDM.
2. Practical Examples: Learn from real-world examples that demonstrate the impact of MDM on business processes and decision-making.
3. Future Trends: Understand how MDM is shaping the future of AI and how you can leverage it for your organization.
4. Interactive Session: Engage with our speakers through Q&A sessions and interactive discussions.

Register Now!

Don't miss out on this opportunity to explore how Master Data Management is impacting the business landscape. Register now to stay ahead of the curve and discover how MDM can be the fuel your organization needs to harness the power of Gen AI and secure operational excellence.

We look forward to seeing you at the webinar!

entry.title: SAP MDG: Auto-fill CR Description by Data Model and CR Type Description
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.
Note 03: There are several ways; this blog is written about one of them.

BADI Responsible: USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGRATION.

Auto-populate the Change Request Description with the Data Model’s CR Type Description so every MDG CR is consistently and meaningfully described. 

Create Custom implementation & assign Data model filter values.

Method Responsible: if_ex_usmd_crequest_integr~get_crequest_attributes.

Code: 

METHOD if_ex_usmd_crequest_integr~get_crequest_attributes.

    SELECT SINGLE a~usmd_creq_type, a~usmd_model,  b~txtmi        
             FROM usmd110c AS a INNER JOIN
                  usmd110t AS b ON a~usmd_creq_type = b~usmd_creq_type
                               AND a~usmd_model EQ @iv_model
             INTO  @DATA(ls_cr_types)
            WHERE b~langu      EQ @SY-langu AND
                  a~usmd_creq_type = @iv_crequest_type.

    IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
      cv_description = ls_cr_types-txtmi.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

 

SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
